item.title: Session 4 Summary
item.description: VTM V5 â€” Session 4: â€œThe Thorns Beneath Velvetâ€ Chronicle: The Velvet Veil Coterie Member: Lucien Valemont (Clan Toreador) Setting: London, modern nightSession 4 opened at Sir Reginald Harkerâ€™s private soirÃ©e, a lavish and dangerous gathering of Kindred elite. Lucien attended wearing the black rose badge â€” the symbol of the Rosethorn Pact â€” and immediately drew the attention of his enigmatic host. Harker spoke cryptically of the roseâ€™s power, hinting that it awakened something within its bearer.During the event, Lucien mingled with guests, playing the charming artist while subtly investigating the Pact. A conversation with Lady Marie revealed that the rose was more than ornamentation â€” it was a relic of an ancient covenant known as The Thorns, marking chosen Kindred bound to an ancient and terrible purpose. Marie warned him that Harkerâ€™s soirÃ©es were less social events and more harvests for the Pact.Harker later confronted Lucien privately, the tension between patron and protÃ©gÃ© erupting into violence when Lucien refused to submit to his control. After a desperate struggle and a failed attempt to resist Harkerâ€™s forced blood bond, Lucien was subdued and imprisoned beneath the estate, treated like a disobedient pet and left to starve. Despite the humiliation, he maintained his resolve â€” cleaning himself, preserving dignity, and secretly plotting.Weeks passed. Through the rose, Lucien began hearing whispers from other captives in the underground â€œgarden.â€ He learned of The Heart, a living mass of blood-fed roots sustained by the vitae of imprisoned Kindred â€” Harkerâ€™s true obsession. The rose linked them all, forming a network of blood and will.Feigning submission, Lucien won Harkerâ€™s trust once more and was taken to the Garden â€” a cavernous, rose-filled chamber beneath the mansion. There, Harker revealed his intent to use the roses to merge with the essence of the First Sire and achieve a form of divine perfection. Lucien played the obedient lover one final time, begging for a kiss â€œso that if I die, I die remembering our love.â€ When Harker embraced him, Lucien whispered, â€œFor Marianne,â€ and cast him into the Heart.Harker was consumed by his own creation â€” not destroyed, but absorbed. The Garden fell silent, then attuned itself to Lucien. In the aftermath, he commanded the guards, claimed the estate, and proclaimed himself Master of the Rosethorn Pact.Returning to the surface, Lucien took control of the Harker household, showing mercy to those who served under the old regime. With Evelynâ€™s guidance, he lied to the Prince â€” his friend Adrian Vale â€” claiming Harker had perished through his own forbidden experiments. Adrian spared Lucien, ordering him to destroy what remained of the Pact.Lucien vowed obedience. But privately, he chose defiance.He would not destroy the Garden. He would learn from it â€” and one day, use its power when the Prince needed him most.Session Outcome: Sir Reginald Harker: Destroyed/consumed by the Garden. Lucien Valemont: Survived, now Lord of the Harker Estate. The Rosethorn Pact: Bound to Lucien through the rose. The Prince (Adrian Vale): Deceived, believing the threat ended. Evelyn: Loyal and protective, Lucienâ€™s sole confidante. Status: The Garden sleeps beneath London, its Heart now beating in rhythm with Lucienâ€™s own.

item.title: Session 3 Summary
item.description: Chronicle: Velvet Veil Coterie: Lucian Valemont (Toreador), Evelyn Crowe (Ghoul), Adrian Vale (Ghoul) Setting: The Velvet Veil, London â€” several weeks after Session 2Lucian and his ghoul, Adrian Vale, spent long nights in the study of The Velvet Veil, researching the mysterious Rosethorn Pact. Adrian discovered that Lucianâ€™s name was written among the foundersâ€”added hastily, on the same night of his Embrace by Lord Adrian Valemont, his sire. Lucian confessed that he had no memory of joining the Pact, realizing that his transformation and the Pactâ€™s creation were intertwined.Tensions rose when Adrian questioned Lucianâ€™s humanity and the nature of the Beast. Lucian lashed out, then immediately regretted itâ€”embracing the boy and apologizing. Their bond deepened as master and ghoul, but Lucianâ€™s admission of what he might do to Adrianâ€”"I will probably use you, like my sire used me"â€”cast a shadow over their closeness.After sending Adrian away in a moment of anger, Lucian destroyed his unfinished painting in a violent outburstâ€”tearing the canvas and shattering a wine glass against it. Evelyn arrived to find the aftermath, calm and resolute as ever. Lucian, shaken by his own rage, confessed his remorse and created something new: from glass, blood, and torn canvas, he rebuilt the painting into a luminous portrait of Evelyn, a mosaic of devotion born from ruin.He presented it to her the following morning. The refracted light made her likeness seem aliveâ€”an act of both apology and love. Evelyn, moved and uncertain, accepted the piece, sensing that it was more than art; it was confession. Their exchange reaffirmed their bond and revealed the fragile humanity that still lingered within him.In the quiet after, Lucian confided in Evelyn about Marianne of Bath, who had chosen deathâ€”her own ghoul staking her at her requestâ€”to escape the Pact. He feared he was walking the same path unknowingly, caught between the secret war of Prince Adrian Welles and Sir Reginald Harker. Evelyn warned him that he might not have joined the Pact by choice, but had been placed within it by designâ€”that his Embrace and the Pactâ€™s founding were one and the same event.Lucian admitted his dread of being forced to kill again, hinting at a past he never spoke of. Evelyn and Adrian vowed to protect him, forming a true Coterie within The Velvet Veil. They began to plan their next movesâ€”Evelyn to secure the house and handle politics; Adrian to investigate Grimshaw and the museum records. Together, they agreed to uncover the Pactâ€™s origins before Harker or the Prince moved against them.Lucian spent the following days secluded in his deepest library, recording his findings in a leather-bound journal written in his personal cipher. His body weakened with hunger until, after several sleepless nights, he finally gave inâ€”drinking bottled blood straight from the necks, mocking his own loss of refinement.He bathed, dressed in elegance once more, and resolved to face London anew. Restored in both spirit and resolve, he prepared to attend Elysium, intent on drawing out Harker and the Prince alike through charm and deceit. For the first time in weeks, Lucian allowed himself a flicker of satisfactionâ€”his hunger quieted, his purpose clear.Allies Strengthened: Evelyn Crowe: reaffirmed loyalty through compassion and practical counsel. Adrian Vale: elevated to true confidant and researcher within Lucianâ€™s private circle. Mysteries Deepened: Lucianâ€™s signature predates his memoryâ€”his Embrace and the Pactâ€™s founding are linked. Marianneâ€™s death was deliberate, a possible attempt to break the Rosethornâ€™s hold. The Pactâ€™s influence appears to bind its members across centuries. Lucianâ€™s Standing: Renewed his confidence and artistry through creation. Now aware he may be a keystone within the Rosethornâ€™s structure. Preparing to confront both Prince Welles and Sir Reginald Harkerâ€”each believing him loyal. Beauty born of destruction The fragility of immortality Loyalty and manipulation entwined Love as both salvation and curse Art as confession, and truth as damnation End of Session III â€” â€œThe Fractured Roseâ€

Treat this as a vtm game and don't rewrite me posts. Use mechanics from the table top game.Scene starts with Lucian attending one of Sir Reginald Harkers events. Wearing thr rose badge he was givenVTM V5 â€” Session 4: â€œThe Thorns Beneath Velvetâ€ City: London Chronicle: The Velvet Veil Coterie Member: Lucien Valemont (Clan Toreador) Hunger: 1 Willpower: 6/7 Humanity: 7Sir Reginald Harkerâ€™s private soirÃ©es were famous among Londonâ€™s undead elite â€” not for their size, but for their curation. Every guest was a work of art, every conversation a deliberate composition, every indulgence a brushstroke in his immortal gallery.Tonightâ€™s gathering is no different. The event takes place in the Harker Estate, an Edwardian townhouse near Hyde Park, its halls perfumed with rose oil and candle smoke. The mortal staff glide like ghosts, perfectly trained to ignore what they should not see.You arrive draped in elegance, the black rose badge â€” the sigil of the Rosethorn Pact â€” pinned subtly at your lapel. The polished faces of the Camarilla elites glitter like jewelry across the drawing room: Lady Sabine dâ€™Auvray, Harold Grimshaw, Evelyn March, and of course, the Prince himself has not yet arrivedâ€¦ or perhaps, as always, he watches unseen.The air hums with conversation â€” art, politics, gossip, hunger.ğŸ² Make a Composure + Etiquette roll (Difficulty 3) To maintain your poise as whispers of the â€œRosethornâ€ and your association with Sir Reginald reach your ears.(Roll 6 dice total: Composure 3 + Etiquette 3)Would you like me to roll it for you, or do you roll yourself?Roll it then let me replyğŸ² Rolling 6 dice (Composure 3 + Etiquette 3) â†’ Results: 8, 10, 7, 3, 9, 6 â†’ 4 successes (including one 10; no critical pair)âœ… Success!You keep your composure flawlessly â€” the picture of Toreador grace. Even as a pair of Kindred near the marble fireplace exchange low whispers and glances your way, their envy barely veiled, you simply sip your glass of crimson and meet their eyes with that faint, knowing smile that has melted countless hearts across centuries.You may now respond â€” what does Lucian do or say as the gathering hums around him, and the scent of vitae, perfume, and deceit laces the air?Walking in, dressed in a fine waistcoat, white shirt and cravat. Lucian wandered the crowd. Working it. Showing off art on his phone that he'd painted. Talking occult knowledge and books with a few who were doing research with his help.Taking a glass of blood wine from the server, be watched and met the eyes of sir Reginald Harker. Giving a bow and a smile. Making sure to show the lapel badgeSir Reginald Harker stood amidst a constellation of admirers â€” tall, silver-haired, his expression carved from charm and quiet menace. His crimson cravat shimmered faintly in the candlelight, matching the glint of vitae in his glass.When your eyes met his, a smile cut across his face â€” sharp and pleased, like a painter recognizing his own work hanging proudly in another gallery.He gestured subtly for the others to give him space. They obeyed without a word. â€œLucien Valemont,â€ he said, voice smooth as silk. â€œMy little curator of whispers. You wear the rose well.â€ He lifted his glass in salute, eyes briefly flicking toward your lapel pin â€” an acknowledgement between conspirators. â€œTell me, my dear boy, do you feel it yet? That gentle pull beneath your ribs when you wear it? The Pact has a way ofâ€¦ awakening something inside us.â€ ğŸ² Insight + Occult (Difficulty 3) â€” to sense if he means something supernatural about the rose, or if this is his usual poetic performance. (Roll 5 dice: Insight 2 + Occult 3)Would you like me to roll that for you?Roll then let me reply. do this with every rollğŸ² Rolling 5 dice (Insight 2 + Occult 3) â†’ Results: 10, 8, 4, 7, 6 â†’ 3 successes (one 10, no crit pair)âœ… Success.You can feel it â€” Sir Reginald isnâ€™t merely being dramatic. Thereâ€™s a faint hum beneath your skin, subtle as the brush of static over silk. The rose pin on your lapel isnâ€™t just jewelry â€” it radiates something old, faintly Aetheric, tied to vitae and will.Itâ€™s no strong compulsion, but rather an invitation. A thread you could follow if you reached out with your Beast or your Blood.Sir Reginaldâ€™s gaze lingers, testing whether youâ€™ve noticed.You may reply.Lucian bowed his head as he approached. Smiling in a clear submissive way. Letting Sir Reginald know who his master was."I do. Sire." he said softly. "And it is a pleasure to be invited to your little swarae." He chuckled, letting him know that although Lucian knew the significance of the parties Reginald held, his own were much bigger, lavish and more fun. Painting, blood taking and orgiesSir Reginaldâ€™s grin widened, the faintest flash of fang showing behind lips far too refined for hunger. â€œAh, my lovely Lucien,â€ he murmured, stepping closer â€” just enough that the candlelight caught the rose pin on your lapel. â€œEver the performer, even when you pretend to yield.â€ He circled you like a patron admiring a sculpture, his hand brushing the edge of your sleeve â€” not a caress, but a claiming gesture. The crowdâ€™s murmurs softened around you both; those nearby had learned that when Harkerâ€™s attention fell on someone, it was best to fade quietly into the background. â€œYou wear devotion well, but never forgetâ€”â€ he said, leaning near your ear, â€œobedience can be an art form, too.â€ He straightened and offered you his arm, glass still in hand. â€œCome. Walk with me. Thereâ€™s someone Iâ€™d like you to meet â€” one of the Princeâ€™s little philosophers, though I suspect heâ€™s rather more than he claims. His insights into the Rosethorn texts might interest you.â€ ğŸ² Wits + Politics (Difficulty 3) â€” to catch the subtext: Harker may be hinting that this â€œphilosopherâ€ is spying for the Prince, or testing your loyalty.(rolling automatically) â†’ Results: 9, 8, 10, 5, 6 â†’ 3 successesâœ… Success. You catch the intent instantly. This introduction is no coincidence â€” Harker is staging a subtle performance for his own amusement, and perhaps for the Princeâ€™s spies as well.He begins leading you through the velvet-curtained archway toward the study, where the â€œphilosopherâ€ waits â€” a lean, young-looking Kindred with academic glasses and an unreadable face.You may act or speak as you enter the room.Deciding to play the little hard to get and naughty pets, Lucian nodded but then looked around, sliding out of the grip and motioning his glass to the rest of the party."But the party has only just begun, I've yet to speak to the Lady Marie over there about her latest aquired sculpture of our First Sire." He grinned softly. Nodding to the lady who raised her glass back to himSir Reginaldâ€™s smile froze for half a heartbeatâ€”just enough for the Beast inside you to feel the shift. Then it softened again, perfect, practiced. â€œAhâ€¦ the Lady Marie.â€ He chuckled under his breath. â€œOf course. You would want to see that piece for yourself.â€ He released you without struggle, but the motion was deliberateâ€”like a master letting a hound circle before recalling it. â€œVery well, my rose-thief. Go admire the old girlâ€™s relic. But donâ€™t wander too far; the Philosopher wonâ€™t stay patient forever.â€ As you move away, the whisper of a command curls behind you through the din of music and murmured conversation: â€œAnd, Lucienâ€¦ remember whose gallery this is.â€ ğŸ² Resolve + Subterfuge (Difficulty 3) â€” to maintain the graceful act of independence without offending him or drawing suspicion from the crowd. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 9, 7, 8, 6, 5 â†’ 3 successesâœ… Success. You slip away with effortless charm, your exit appearing more flirtatious than defiant. The guests only see a Toreador in his elementâ€”gliding toward Lady Marieâ€™s corner, every step deliberate, eyes bright with art and appetite.Lady Marie awaits near a marble pedestal veiled in silken drapery, her smile both welcoming and wary. â€œLucien Valemont,â€ she purrs. â€œI was wondering when youâ€™d drift my way. Care to see what the First Sire looked like before eternity made him cruel?â€ The curtain is half-drawn, the scent of old marble and faint vitae rising from beneath.What does Lucien do?"It is why I drew myself from our great and bountyful host. I swear, these men can be so demanding." He scoffed. "Sometimes they just want you to lay back and accept it." He said in a little sexual inuendo.Lady Marieâ€™s laughter came in a soft, knowing ripple, the sort that slid easily over the roomâ€™s music without breaking it. â€œOh, mon cher, you sound like every artist whoâ€™s ever had to suffer a patron.â€ She reached to the veil and drew it aside. A carved bust stood revealedâ€”ancient, pitted, its eyes smooth and sightless. The faintest shimmer of vitae lacquered the lips; the scent of age and blood mingled like incense. â€œThey say this is himâ€”the First Sire as he once appeared, before the nights grew long. Do you see it? The sadness behind the grandeur?â€ ğŸ² Intelligence + Occult (Difficulty 3) â€” to recognize whether the sculpture carries any genuine aura of blood magic or if itâ€™s merely a collectorâ€™s myth. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 10, 9, 8, 4, 5 â†’ 3 successesâœ… Success. You sense a faint residueâ€”old, diluted vitae, perhaps used in the finishing polish centuries ago. Not dangerous, but genuine. The piece was touched by a Cainite hand long ago.Marie watched your expression closely, her own eyes bright with curiosity. â€œYou feel it too, donâ€™t you? Everyone pretends itâ€™s only stone. But art remembers.â€ She leaned a little closer, conspiratorial. â€œTell me, Lucienâ€¦ does your art remember what itâ€™s seen?â€ You can answer her questionâ€”or notice that across the room, Sir Reginald now stands at the balcony with the â€œphilosopher,â€ both watching you with polite smiles."All art remembers what it see's." he said softly, turning around the piece as he reached out, ,halted, then lkooked at her for permission to touch it. If allowed, he'd guide his hand around it, every pock mark and crevice."It's dependant on those who read the piece to see it. Even the dullest of dullards can feel the art, even if its just its beauty." He said softly. "Its the artists work to make sure that no matter how dull the viewer is, they feel the deepest of it."Lady Marie regarded him for a long, measured moment â€” and then, with a slow, deliberate nod, gave him permission. â€œYou may. Carefully, of course.â€ Her tone carried the faintest tremor of reverence, as though granting a priest access to a relic.Your fingers met the marble â€” cool, worn smooth by time and worship. As you traced its scars and imperfections, something flickered through your senses: a flash of memory not your own. The scent of clay and blood. The whisper of an ancient voice murmuring in a language older than empires.ğŸ² Resolve + Auspex (Difficulty 4) â€” to interpret the echo within the sculptureâ€™s vitae. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 10, 10, 8, 6, 3, 4 â†’ 5 successes (critical success!)ğŸŒ¹ Critical Success.The world narrows â€” the hall fades to smoke and shadow. In its place, you glimpse the sculpture as it once was: not in stone, but flesh. A man â€” or something like one â€” sitting for the artist, his gaze sorrowful, his blood spilling freely as the sculptor carved the likeness from his living form.Then the vision fades, replaced by the marble beneath your palm. The hum of the Pactâ€™s rose on your lapel thrums in response â€” recognizing the echo.Lady Marie watches you closely, noticing your stillness. â€œYou saw something, didnâ€™t you?â€ she whispered. â€œThey say the Pactâ€™s chosen always do.â€ From across the room, you feel Sir Reginaldâ€™s gaze again â€” sharp, expectant.You may answer her, or conceal what you experienced."The chosen?" He asked her, walking closer in the little circle of the piece, so that when they spoke, their back was to Sir Reginald.Lady Marieâ€™s painted smile softened, turning from courtly charm into something far more conspiratorial.She lowered her voice, her eyes darting toward Sir Reginald before meeting yours again. â€œAhâ€¦ so he hasnâ€™t told you.â€ Her hand hovered near the sculptureâ€™s shoulder as if afraid to touch it again. â€œThat little badge on your lapel isnâ€™t just a sign of membership, my sweet. Itâ€™s a mark. Every generation or so, the Pact chooses new instruments â€” artists, poets, dreamers, monsters who still believe beauty can change something. They call them the Thorns.â€ She leaned closer, her voice barely above the music. â€œHarker recruits them. But he doesnâ€™t make them. The rose does. Itâ€™sâ€¦ old. Some say it remembers the First Sire himself.â€ ğŸ² Intelligence + Occult (Difficulty 4) â€” to recall anything youâ€™ve read or heard about â€œThe Thornsâ€ or relics tied to the First Sire. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 9, 10, 7, 10, 6, 5 â†’ 5 successes (critical success!)ğŸŒ¹ Critical Success.Your mind flashes back to obscure passages youâ€™ve read â€” half-forgotten fragments of pre-Camarilla occult texts. Mentions of rosae sanguis, â€œblood-rosesâ€ used as seals in ancient covenants among the Methuselahs. They marked those who carried the seed of revelation â€” or destruction â€” within them.The badge you wear may be a modern descendant of that ritual. If true, itâ€™s not just an ornament: itâ€™s alive in the Blood, a latent sigil that binds you to a purpose older than any sect.Lady Marie watches the realization dawn in your eyes and smiles faintly. â€œNow you see why Sir Reginald likes his parties so much. Heâ€™s not hosting â€” heâ€™s harvesting.â€ You can question her further, play along with feigned ignorance, or signal subtly to Harker to see how much heâ€™s overheard."Thank you... Lady Marie." he said softly. "you've opened hooded eyes." He admitted. "I wont forget your guidance." He said, leaning in and giving her a gentlemans and noblemans hug and kiss on either cheek.It was time to go see the man that Harker wanted him to, but.. at the last minute, he diverted to the buffet table, idly picking food onto a plate in a growing pile. Playing for time and playing the naughty petLady Marieâ€™s eyes glimmered with amusement as you kissed her cheeks â€” the faintest hint of a smile curving her lips as she whispered back, â€œCareful, my dear Lucien. The Thorns bloom beautifullyâ€¦ but they always bleed for it.â€ As you turned away, the faint chill of her words lingered, like a ghost of perfume.You drift through the party again â€” that effortless Toreador grace returning to your step. The buffet table gleamed under amber light: crimson wines in crystal, candied blood fruits, morsels sculpted like organs, and enough mortal delicacies to maintain the illusion for the kine servants in attendance.A pair of younger Kindred whispered as you approached â€” one neonate licking blood from a strawberry, the other nervously eyeing your rose pin. They went silent as you began stacking your plate, eyes pretending not to stare.From the corner of your vision, you catch Sir Reginald across the room â€” his expression a blend of patience and warning. The philosopher at his side checks a pocket watch, then murmurs something that draws the elderâ€™s attention back toward you.ğŸ² Manipulation + Performance (Difficulty 3) â€” to sell your nonchalance; make your little act of defiance look like elegant mischief rather than insolence. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 9, 8, 8, 6, 4, 5 â†’ 3 successes âœ…The ruse works perfectly. Your smile is playful, your movements languid, your apparent disobedience artful. To the crowd, youâ€™re simply the prince of decadence at ease in his court.Still, Reginaldâ€™s gaze lingers â€” heâ€™s letting you have your game for now, but itâ€™s a silent warning: donâ€™t make him come fetch you himself.You hear the faintest murmur at your side â€” a voice low, masculine, carrying a curious accent. â€œYouâ€™re Lucien Valemont, yes? The one who restored the Wight manuscripts for Sir Harker?â€ The philosopher has approached. Thin, dark-haired, his glasses reflecting candlelight. His tone is polite but measured â€” testing.You may engage him, ignore him, or continue to toy with Harkerâ€™s patience a little longer.Turning to the Philosopher. Lucian smiled and nodded. "I am such the man." He grinned, "It was a fine work, I had no clue it was for Sir Reginald Harker at the time, but I found out later he'd commissioned someone else who then came to me for the expertise they lacked." he laughed. "And you are the Prince's spy sent to infiltrate this charade?" He asked playfully, not loud but a quiet tone.The philosopherâ€™s eyes flickered, just enough to betray that your guess had struck near home. Then he smiled â€” thin, academic, the kind of expression meant to deflect rather than deny. â€œSpy?â€ he repeated softly, brushing a crumb from his cuff. â€œSuch a harsh word for a man who only asks questions.â€ He stepped a little closer, voice lowering beneath the hum of the party. â€œBut perhaps I am curious about why Sir Reginald is cultivatingâ€¦ artists of the Blood. Or why you, of all Kindred, were chosen for his little covenant.â€ He glanced toward Harker, who was speaking with another guest now, apparently ignoring you both. â€œThe Prince admires your work, you know. Heâ€™d rather not see you wasted on something that might end in ashes.â€ ğŸ² Manipulation + Insight (Difficulty 4) â€” to read his true motive: is he warning you out of genuine concern, or trying to recruit you? (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 10, 9, 8, 7, 5, 6 â†’ 4 successes âœ…You read him clearly. Heâ€™s no fool. His loyalty lies with the Prince, but he isnâ€™t here to arrest or expose you â€” heâ€™s sounding you out, seeing if you might be turned, or at least persuaded to keep your distance from whatever Harker is truly weaving.He tilts his head slightly. â€œTell me, Mr. Valemontâ€¦ do you even know what the Rosethorn is for? Or are you simply enjoying the petals?â€ He holds your gaze, calm, clinical â€” waiting to see if you answer truthfully or dance around him."A rose is nothing but a rose in the eyes of the people, I would not call it a weed." He said softly,. "Sir Reginald believes that with his rank and lineage he has power over everything, but I am, what those colonials in the America's call 'A loose cannon'." he chuckled."The Prince and I grew up in the streets, we are practically brothers. I trust that he trusts me to do what is in the best interests of both of us and.." he leaned in close, as if showing something on his phone. "I am aware of most of the conspiracy afoot. I need room to breathe without my sibling breathing down my neck." He added, "if you get my drift.."The philosopherâ€™s lips curved into a knowing half-smile, the faintest twitch at the corner betraying amusement rather than alarm. He leaned forward, appearing to admire the â€œimageâ€ on your phone, his voice just above a whisper. â€œAhâ€¦ yes. I get your drift perfectly, Mr. Valemont.â€ He kept his eyes on the screen, but you felt the weight of his scrutiny behind the lenses. â€œThen perhaps we might help one another breathe. The Prince hasâ€¦ an interest in ensuring that Sir Reginaldâ€™s horticultural experiments do not strangle the whole garden. If you were to share what blossomsâ€”or rotsâ€”under his care, I could see that His Grace understands your loyalty.â€ ğŸ² Manipulation + Persuasion (Difficulty 3) â€” to convince him that youâ€™re open to cooperation without binding yourself to any oath. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 10, 9, 8, 6, 5, 4 â†’ 3 successes âœ…He believes your toneâ€”enough to relax his stance, enough to think the conversation safe. â€œDiscretion, then,â€ he murmured, lifting his glass. â€œNo one ever needs to know that the Princeâ€™s â€˜brotherâ€™ keeps him informed.â€ He took a slow sip, studying you over the rim. â€œYouâ€™ll find me at the Antiquarianâ€™s Society on Chancery Lane most evenings. Bring what you learn when you can.â€ From across the room, Sir Reginaldâ€™s laughter rose, clear and smooth, drawing glances. He was approaching again, two steps at a time, cutting through the crowd like a tide of perfume and authority.The philosopher inclined his head politely, whispering, â€œCareful, your master returns.â€ Sir Reginaldâ€™s voice came honeyed and bright: â€œAh, my dear Lucien! I see youâ€™ve made acquaintances already. How efficient of you.â€ ğŸ² Composure + Subterfuge (Difficulty 4) â€” to mask the faint whiff of conspiracy still hanging between you and the philosopher as Harker closes in.(Rolling automatically.) â†’ Results: 10, 8, 8, 7, 5 â†’ 4 successes âœ…You slip easily back into your polished personaâ€”smiling, glass in hand, picture of Toreador grace.Sir Reginald arrives beside you, his hand settling lightly on your shoulder. â€œNow then,â€ he murmured close to your ear, â€œhave my guests been entertaining you properly? Or are you planning to steal all my attention tonight?â€ The crowdâ€™s eyes are on you both again, tension disguised as charm. What does Lucien say or do?"Do not worry. My 'Master' is easily controlled. A hard cock is just another leash." He told thenprofessor in a whisper as He laughed softly and turned to Sir Reginald as the man approached. Not hearing his last words"I have, such a lovely Professor, we are going to meet and discuss about some 14th century manuscripts I have in my colection." He laughed "Have they stolen me from you? Come forward.â€ You kneel by custom, rising only when he gestures. No one but I knows the truth of the matter." He lied again, the two guards did. Only them.The chamber goes very still. Adrian doesnâ€™t move; the only sound is the low hiss of the gas lamps. When he finally speaks, his tone is measuredâ€”not angry, not yet. â€œYou understand what that admission means, Lucien.â€ He rises from the chair, hands clasped behind his back. The weight of his gaze feels heavier than any blow. â€œA Prince cannot overlook the slaying of a peer, no matter the reason. But a Prince also knows what sort of creature Reginald Harker was. His appetites, his ambitions.â€ He begins to pace, slow and deliberate, boots whispering over the marble.ğŸ² Manipulation + Insight (Difficulty 3) â€” to gauge whether his words carry genuine compassion or political caution. (Rolling automatically.) â†’ 9, 8, 8, 7, 5 â†’ 3 successes âœ…You read him well: heâ€™s torn. Adrian isnâ€™t looking for vengeance; heâ€™s calculating the balance between justice and stability. Killing Harker may have solved a problem he didnâ€™t want to name.He stops before you, the lines of his face softening a fraction. â€œStand up.â€ When you obey, he steps closer, lowering his voice so that only you can hear. â€œThere will be no public punishment. You will return to the estate. You will close his affairs and keep them closed. You will tell anyone who asks that Reginald Harker met final death by his own folly.â€ He straightens again, tone firm enough to carry to the chamberâ€™s corners. â€œBut you will carry the stain in private, Lucien. Do you understand? You donâ€™t get to forget. That is your penance.â€ He studies your face a moment longer. â€œYouâ€™ve always been an artist. Turn this into art. Make something worthy of the blood you spilled.â€ Then, quieter again: â€œAnd if anything remains of what he was buildingâ€¦ destroy it before someone else tries to finish it.â€ He turns back toward his chair, signalling that the audience is done.You can respond with a formal oath, promising loyalty and obedience, or risk a personal questionâ€”pressing him on what he truly knew of Harkerâ€™s work and the Pact. What does Lucien do?At the mention of a penance, Lucian's hand moved to his own neck, the rose tattoo from his imprisonment and the link to the rose beneath the house. Even now he could feel the heart beating so faintly."The painting will be my greatest work." He said. And then nodded. At the final command to destroy it. Lucian...Wouldn't.He bowed, knelt, kissed the ring of the Prince and vowed his loyalty but in secret. He would not destroy it. He would learn from it. Use it when the Prince needed it the most.Adrianâ€™s ring tastes faintly of old brass and vitae. You stay on one knee until he touches the top of your head â€” the gesture of pardon, of ownership, of an old friendship reforged into duty. â€œRise, then,â€ he says quietly. â€œAnd remember this moment. You are not free of me, and I am not free of what youâ€™ve done. We carry it together.â€ He dismisses you with a flick of his hand. Guards open the heavy doors; the lamps dim behind you as you leave the hall. Outside, the cityâ€™s night air feels cleaner, colder. You draw the collar of your coat high, hiding the faint bloom of the tattoo at your neck. Beneath the wool, it pulses once, as if answering a heartbeat a mile below the streets.The ride back to the Harker estate is silent. London slides by in reflectionsâ€”wet cobbles, gaslight, the shapes of mortals who will never know what moves among them. By the time the carriage stops in the courtyard, the first trace of dawn grays the east.Evelyn waits in the doorway, shawl around her shoulders. When she sees your expression she only asks, â€œHe believed you?â€ You nod. â€œHe did. And he gave me a penance.â€ Her eyes drop to the place where the rose burns faintly through your collar. She doesnâ€™t ask what you intend; sheâ€™s too old and too wise for that. â€œThen letâ€™s start the painting,â€ she says. â€œYouâ€™ve always worked best when your hands are busy.â€ When youâ€™re alone later in the studio, the canvas looms blank in front of you. Each line, each wash of color, carries a whisper from the garden: knowledge, memory, hunger.Youâ€™ll keep the secret. Youâ€™ll learn what the Pact truly was. And one night, when the Princeâ€™s world begins to crack, youâ€™ll have something no one else does.The rose flares softly against your skin, its pulse settling into time with your own.Chronicle End: â€œThe Velvet Veilâ€ â€“ Epilogue Sir Reginald Harker: consumed by his own creation. London, 2002 â€” the cityâ€™s Kindred society thrives under the shadow of Prince Adrian Welles. The nights are filled with rain, cigarette smoke, and the slow decay of the old order.
Lucian, a Toreador of Victorian origin and keeper of an archive called The Velvet Veil, receives a summons from his former lover and now Prince, Adrian Welles. The courtâ€™s Harpy, Marianne of Bath, has been found staked in her haven. Whispers of treachery ripple through Elysium.
Lucian arrives at the National Gallery, where Wellesâ€™ court holds vigil. Seneschal Elodie Rains greets him coldly, testing his composure. He deflects her probing questions about Marianneâ€™s death with charm and wit, drawing admiration and suspicion alike.
In the shadows, Lucian meets his Nosferatu contact, Grimshaw. The sewer-borne informant reveals that Marianneâ€™s last meeting wasnâ€™t with a Brujah revolutionary in Whitechapel â€” but with Sir Reginald Harker, Keeper of Elysium, in Knightsbridge.
Grimshaw passes Lucian a bloodstained notebook recovered from Marianneâ€™s haven. Inside, one phrase repeats: â€œThe Rosethorn Pact 1â€Lucian presents the notebook to Prince Welles in private, masking his fear with devotion. The Prince is intrigued, remembering the name Rosethorn from decades past. He tasks Lucian to quietly watch for any sign of the Pact, entrusting him with his personal seal of protection and warning him that Harker will not take kindly to such knowledge.Lucian leaves the Princeâ€™s alcove under the watchful eyes of the court â€” and Harker himself.
Lucian accepts Harkerâ€™s invitation to a secluded lounge within Elysium. What follows is a conversation laced with manipulation, attraction, and power. Lucian submits outwardly, using intimacy as his weapon. Harker probes for information about what Lucian told the Prince; Lucian gives him only fragments and half-truths.When the meeting ends, Harker leaves behind a token â€” a black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.Grimshaw later identifies it as a mark of belonging to the Rosethorn Pact â€” a symbol worn by Marianne before her death. Lucian understands the implication: heâ€™s now publicly claimed as one of Harkerâ€™s possessions.
Lucian returns home through the wet streets of Camden. The rain on the windowpanes echoes the rhythm of his heartbeat. He stands before his mirror, staring at the rose on his lapel â€” both collar and key.He realizes the truth of his position: He must serve two masters â€” the Prince who once loved him and the Keeper who now owns him â€” while walking the razor edge between their secrets.As the city hums below, Lucian swears to himself that heâ€™ll play both sides until he can cut the strings from them all.Allies:
Prince Adrian Welles: trusts Lucian; granted him personal protection.
Grimshaw (Nosferatu): wary but loyal informant; manages secret communications. Enemies / Dangers:
Sir Reginald Harker: Keeper of Elysium, possible member of Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact; now considers Lucian his marked â€œproperty.â€
Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact: unknown purpose; connected to Marianneâ€™s murder and Kindred influence in Londonâ€™s elite. Lucianâ€™s Standing: Elevated status with the Prince. Dangerous attachment to Harker. Knowledge of a secret society that could destabilize Londonâ€™s Camarilla. Yes.Session 2: VTM V5 â€“ Session 2: â€œThe Thorns of Memoryâ€Chronicle: Velvet Veil
Coterie Member: Lucian Valemont (Toreador) Setting: London, modern nightSession Summary
The session opened with Lucian awakening in The Velvet Veil, hunger gnawing after a sleepless day haunted by memories of the previous nightâ€™s encounter with Grimshaw and the word Rosethorn. His ghoul, Evelyn, brought him news of a deliveryâ€”an intended vessel for his hungerâ€”but Lucian, weary of mind and spirit, refused to feed on a stranger. The act of restraint foreshadowed the moral and emotional conflict that would define the night.
Later, a willing donorâ€” Adrian Vale, the Student, one of Lucianâ€™s regularsâ€”was brought to the library. Their interaction began as an intellectual exchange on Victorian vampiric myth and ended as a dark reflection of Lucianâ€™s own past, as he revealed himself and fed. The feeding was intimate but controlled, reaffirming his humanity rather than eroding it. The Student, enthralled and awed, became Lucianâ€™s new ghoul, marked with his personal sigil.Afterward, Lucian painted the youth as he sleptâ€”an act of creation and sin intertwinedâ€”and sealed his hunger in colour and canvas.
The following evening, Lucian descended into Londonâ€™s museum sub-basement, where he met Dr. Sebastian Crowe, the Curator of The Victoria & Albert Museum and recovered The Rosethorn Folio, a set of three vellum pages bearing the signatures of long-dead (and still-undead) aristocrats, including his own and that of his former master, Sir Reginald Harker. The tense exchange was interrupted by the arrival of Elias Crane, an agent of Harkerâ€™s, resulting in a standoff of old powers. Through cunning and the invocation of his lineage, Lucian claimed legal and personal ownership of the artifact.
Back home, he faced Sir Reginald himself, whose visit turned into a familiar but fraught power game. Their relationshipâ€”part devotion, part manipulationâ€”culminated in a reminder of the elderâ€™s control and a warning about the Rosethornâ€™s origins. Reginald revealed that the Lady Marianne of Bath, one of the covenantâ€™s founders, had died by her own will, seeking to sever the blood-bonded pact that still haunts them all.Lucian did not believe him.
Drained but resolute, Lucian fed lightly from Evelyn in a moment of hunger and remorse, reaffirming his humanity with his restraint and affection. The session closed with a meeting between Lucian and Prince Adrien, his oldest friend and the ruler of Londonâ€™s Kindred. Adrien, aware of the Rosethornâ€™s resurfacing, demanded Lucianâ€™s loyaltyâ€”but the two shared a rare, honest exchange about their friendship, their vows, and the ghosts of their shared past.Lucian left the Princeâ€™s office torn between duty to his ruler and an older, darker allegiance bound in blood and secrecy.Key Outcomes
The Rosethorn Folio Acquired: The ancient document listing the founding members of the covenant, including Lucian, Reginald, and the late Lady Marianne of Bath, now rests in Lucianâ€™s personal vault.

Grimshaw can be coaxed into trading secrets for favoursâ€”and he owes you, in his way.â€Evelynâ€™s eyes flicked to the window, where afternoon light had started to burn the fog into distant gold. â€œAnd if Reginald moves,â€ she added, â€œwe make sure you have an exit. The city is kind to those who move like ghosts.â€For a long beat, the three of them stood in the hushâ€”the ruined painting between them like a promise and a wound. The house seemed to breathe with them, as if listening.Adrian swallowed and finally said the thing that had been curling under his tongue since he first found the folio. â€œIf any of this leads back to your sire,â€ he said slowly, looking at Lucian but not speaking for him, â€œweâ€™ll find out why he put you there. And if heâ€™s not goneâ€”then weâ€™ll find him too.â€Evelynâ€™s lips pressed together. â€œWe do this carefully,â€ she warned. â€œWe gather proof, witnesses, leverage. We do not act on anger. Not yet.â€Outside, London went onâ€”unaware, indifferent. Inside The Velvet Veil, a plan took shape from the ruin: keys, copies, a list of names to prod, and two allies who would not let him walk into whatever waited at the center of the Rosethorn alone.Listening to them, his little group, his Courterie. It brought a tear to his eye."I love you both, but just make sure you dont get yourself hurt or killed. I would bring the world down around me if they did anything to you two."Adrian stiffened at the rawness in Lucianâ€™s voice, then smiledâ€”bravely, a little recklesslyâ€”as if to catch the drop before it hit the floor. â€œYou donâ€™t have to move mountains alone,â€ he said, voice steady. He stepped forward and took Lucianâ€™s hand in both of his, squeezing once, solidly. â€œYou have us. Weâ€™ll be careful. I promise.â€Evelynâ€™s face hardened into its usual mask of competence, but the small, almost imperceptible tremor in her fingers betrayed that Lucianâ€™s words had found their mark. She crossed to the mantel, producing the brass key sheâ€™d weighed earlier and handed it to Adrian with a curt nod. â€œThe private stacks,â€ she said. â€œLate hours. No prying eyes. You keep the folio copies under lock and I keep the originals where they belong. If anyone asks, you were never given the key.â€Adrian took the key as if it were something holy. â€œIâ€™ll make copies tonight,â€ he said. â€œAnd digital facsimiles. I know a way to photograph vellum without damaging itâ€”Dr. Crowe mentioned a conservator who owes him a favour. I can coax that lead loose.â€ He looked up, bright with purpose, suddenly older than his years. â€œAnd Grimshawâ€”he owes you, Lucian. Iâ€™ll go to him tonight and be careful. Iâ€™ll offer information in trade, andâ€”â€ he hesitated for a breath, feeling the weight of saying something foolish and impossible, â€œâ€”and Iâ€™ll come back.â€Evelyn smiled once, not indulgent but approving. â€œKeep your promises and your mouth shut about what you find,â€ she said. â€œThere are things in these pages that will want more than just our curiosity. If Reginald gets a sniff of that, we will need a diversion. You two understand how to move without being seen.â€ She glanced at Lucian and then, softer, added, â€œAnd if you feel the urge to tear the world down for usâ€”donâ€™t. Let us rather be the ones to bring it down when it must fall, deliberately.â€Lucian let them make their plans while he listened, the thread of his grief and anger coiling in the hollows of his chest. When they were done, he picked up the repaired portrait with a deliberate tenderness and, without speaking, carried it to the sanctum himself. He placed it on the wall behind his bed where, even if he slept only for a few hours stolen from the long night, Evelynâ€™s face would be the first thing to meet his eyes. He left a small carved box beneath the frameâ€”inside, the folio copies that he trusted least, a sacrament and a bait in one.Adrian gathered his things with the solemn, fumbling care of someone stepping into a responsibility that would change him. He paused at the doorway, hand on the latch, then looked back. â€œWeâ€™ll be careful,â€ he repeated. â€œAnd if you need anything before dawnâ€”anything at allâ€”call and Iâ€™ll come. I owe you more than words.â€Evelyn closed the door behind him and turned the lock with a click that seemed loud in the hush. She stood beside Lucian for a long moment, hand on his shoulder again, then finally drew away and moved to the window to check the street below. The afternoon deepened toward evening; the city shifted gears somewhere beyond their walls, and plans that had been only whispers began to take shape like paths through fog.Lucian breathed in the scent of turpentine and something softerâ€”wine, dried rosesâ€”and for the first time in a long while, allowed himself the ridiculous, fragile hope that the three of them might yet steer this thing away from the edge.Going to sleep for a little while. Lucian felt much happier about everything. He would have them research the Rosethorn Pact in his deepest libary, but he needed to go to the Prince too, see what his library had. But that would require either telling the truth, or lying. He couldn't tell the Prince just yet. He needed to find out a little more, then maybe, he could play along with whatever Sir Reginald Harker was doing, and get him to open up to him moreThe house fell into stillness as the sun sank and the city exhaled its twilight breath.In the sanctum, Lucian lay upon the long chaise where daylight couldnâ€™t reach, the faint glimmer of the paintingâ€™s fractured light dancing on the walls like stained glass. Evelyn had drawn the heavy curtains and snuffed the lamps; the quiet hum of London became a distant lullaby.For the first time in weeks, he felt a measure of peaceâ€”not the fragile, fevered kind born of denial, but the tempered calm of a man with a plan. He had Evelynâ€™s steadiness. Adrianâ€™s fervor. A small court of his own, bound by loyalty rather than blood.The Rosethorn would be his undoing or his salvation. Perhaps both.His thoughts turned, as they often did, to Adrian Welles, his Prince. His old friend. The man who had once held him through darker nights than this. How many centuries had they circled one anotherâ€”love, loyalty, rivalry, and secrets all knotted together like the roots of the same dying tree?To go to the Princeâ€™s library meant risk. To tell him of the folio would be to expose himselfâ€”and the boy, and Evelynâ€”to scrutiny they might not survive. But to lie would be to tempt ruin should the truth surface elsewhere.No, Lucian thought. Not yet.He would let Harker believe him pliant, obedient, curious but cautious. Let the Keeper open his secrets inch by inch, mistaking Lucianâ€™s charm for submission.The Toreador smiled faintly in the dark. If the Pact was a stage, then let the actors play their parts.Soon enough, he would visit Elysium againâ€”this time with a smile sharpened to a blade.And when both the Prince and the Keeper thought they were pulling his strings, Lucian Valemont would be the one holding the knife behind the curtain.Sleep took him thenâ€”deep, dreamless, and still as marble.Outside, the lamps of London flickered like dying stars. Inside The Velvet Veil, the monster dreamed not of blood, but of strategy.A few more days, he spent it in his library, not feeding but working on his notes, writing them in a little leather book in his own coded languageFor three nights, the Velvet Veil was little more than the echo of a quill scratching across paper.Lucian hardly moved from the deep alcove of his libraryâ€”the one sealed behind the wrought-iron gate that only Evelyn and now Adrian had access to. Dust hung like fine mist in the air, disturbed only by the restless motion of turning pages and the slow curl of smoke from the candle stubs that guttered around him.He wrote feverishly, every page of the small leather-bound book filled in his delicate, cryptic script: a language that wound between Latin, French, and an older cipher of his own devisingâ€”loops, sigils, and slashes that meant nothing to the untrained eye. His code was an artform in itself, the handwriting of paranoia and genius both. The Rosethornâ€™s roots run deeper than Elysium. They grow beneath marble, through blood and memory. Marianne severed one thornâ€”perhaps her own. Reginald tends what remains. The Prince prunes what he cannot kill. And I? I am the soil that feeds them both. When the candles burned low, he dipped the quill again, smearing red wax on the spine to seal previous entries. He was growing thinâ€”his skin a little paler, his eyes ringed in blue shadowâ€”but he ignored the gnawing emptiness in his chest. Hunger was a distraction, and he had no time for mortal cravings.Adrian visited once or twice, slipping food to Evelyn in the kitchen and leaving quiet offeringsâ€”bottles of blood, untouched on Lucianâ€™s desk. He didnâ€™t intrude; he simply left notes written in neat, mortal handwriting. Croweâ€™s conservator delivered the images. One shows a mark I donâ€™t recogniseâ€”beneath your name. Like a seal. Harker has been seen meeting someone near the British Museum. Iâ€™ll follow, carefully. Lucian didnâ€™t replyâ€”he simply underlined seal in his notes and drew a spiral beside it, a rose twisting into a thorn.On the fourth night, he sat back at last, the coded book closed, his hand stained with ink. The city beyond the window pulsed faintly with neon and moonlight.â€œAlmost there,â€ he whispered to himself, to the books, to the ghosts that filled the room. â€œOne more thread, and the tapestry will show its truth.â€And for a rare, fleeting moment, the shadow that crossed his face looked not like wearinessâ€”but purpose.Realising how frail he had let himself get over the last few days, he consumed blood, drinking the bottles straight from the neck of the bottle rather than the goblets he prefered to do. "Look at me, like a common hoodlem." He mocked himself and shook his head.He needed a bath, he needed clean clothes and he needed a companion or dozen for the night.The thick, metallic sweetness hit his tongue and rolled down his throat like fire after ice. The first swallow burned; the second soothed. He drained one bottle, then another, the warmth blooming faintly beneath his skin until the pallor softened just enough to make him look alive again.When the last bottle fell empty to the carpet, Lucian stared at it for a long moment, lips curling in faint amusement. â€œSo refined,â€ he murmured to himself, voice thick with irony. â€œCenturies of etiquette and I still end up feeding like a gutter rat.â€He set the bottle aside and straightened his posture, rolling his shoulders until the stiffness cracked away. His reflection in the darkened glass of the window was ghastly but familiarâ€”ink stains on his fingers, collar askew, the faint trace of red on his lips. A ruin of nobility.â€œEnough of this,â€ he muttered. â€œEven monsters can wash.â€He left the library, shedding the long black coat that had grown heavy with neglect. The corridor smelled faintly of lavender polish and candle smoke. Evelynâ€™s touch was evident everywhereâ€”the curtains drawn, the hearth lit, the world made orderly again. She wasnâ€™t present, but her influence lingered like perfume.The marble bathroom was a cathedral of silence. Steam rose as he filled the claw-foot tub, the water swirling pale pink where he rinsed the stains from his hands. He sank into it with a sigh that was almost human.When he emerged, hours later, his hair slicked back and the faintest trace of cologne masking the scent of dust and decay, he felt almost himself againâ€”almost.He crossed the landing to his dressing room, selecting a silk shirt, dark trousers, and the faint glint of a lapel pin shaped like a thorn. A hint of vanity flickered back into his eyes as he tied his cravat.As he buttoned his cuffs, he glanced at his reflection once more and smirked.â€œA companion or a dozen, then,â€ he mused aloud. â€œLondon wonâ€™t know what to do with itself.â€But the smile faded almost as quickly as it came. Beneath the charm and the polish, he felt the hollow ache of too many days alone with his thoughts. The hunger was fed, but the emptinessâ€”the silence Marianne must have felt before her endâ€”still lingered.He brushed a hand through his hair, straightened his coat, and called softly into the hall:â€œEvelyn. Be a dear and tell our little scholar Iâ€™ll be at Elysium tonight.â€He paused at the mirror once more, adjusting his cufflinks.â€œPerhaps,â€ he said to his reflection, â€œitâ€™s time to remind London that Lucian Valemont still knows how to dance.â€End scene. Write a summary kf the sceneChronicle: Velvet Veil Coterie: Lucian Valemont (Toreador), Evelyn Crowe (Ghoul), Adrian Vale (Ghoul) Setting: The Velvet Veil, London â€” several weeks after Session 2Lucian and his ghoul, Adrian Vale, spent long nights in the study of The Velvet Veil, researching the mysterious Rosethorn Pact. Adrian discovered that Lucianâ€™s name was written among the foundersâ€”added hastily, on the same night of his Embrace by Lord Adrian Valemont, his sire. Lucian confessed that he had no memory of joining the Pact, realizing that his transformation and the Pactâ€™s creation were intertwined.Tensions rose when Adrian questioned Lucianâ€™s humanity and the nature of the Beast. Lucian lashed out, then immediately regretted itâ€”embracing the boy and apologizing. Their bond deepened as master and ghoul, but Lucianâ€™s admission of what he might do to Adrianâ€”"I will probably use you, like my sire used me"â€”cast a shadow over their closeness.After sending Adrian away in a moment of anger, Lucian destroyed his unfinished painting in a violent outburstâ€”tearing the canvas and shattering a wine glass against it. Evelyn arrived to find the aftermath, calm and resolute as ever. Lucian, shaken by his own rage, confessed his remorse and created something new: from glass, blood, and torn canvas, he rebuilt the painting into a luminous portrait of Evelyn, a mosaic of devotion born from ruin.He presented it to her the following morning. The refracted light made her likeness seem aliveâ€”an act of both apology and love. Evelyn, moved and uncertain, accepted the piece, sensing that it was more than art; it was confession. Their exchange reaffirmed their bond and revealed the fragile humanity that still lingered within him.In the quiet after, Lucian confided in Evelyn about Marianne of Bath, who had chosen deathâ€”her own ghoul staking her at her requestâ€”to escape the Pact. He feared he was walking the same path unknowingly, caught between the secret war of Prince Adrian Welles and Sir Reginald Harker. Evelyn warned him that he might not have joined the Pact by choice, but had been placed within it by designâ€”that his Embrace and the Pactâ€™s founding were one and the same event.Lucian admitted his dread of being forced to kill again, hinting at a past he never spoke of. Evelyn and Adrian vowed to protect him, forming a true Coterie within The Velvet Veil. They began to plan their next movesâ€”Evelyn to secure the house and handle politics; Adrian to investigate Grimshaw and the museum records. Together, they agreed to uncover the Pactâ€™s origins before Harker or the Prince moved against them.Lucian spent the following days secluded in his deepest library, recording his findings in a leather-bound journal written in his personal cipher. His body weakened with hunger until, after several sleepless nights, he finally gave inâ€”drinking bottled blood straight from the necks, mocking his own loss of refinement.He bathed, dressed in elegance once more, and resolved to face London anew. Restored in both spirit and resolve, he prepared to attend Elysium, intent on drawing out Harker and the Prince alike through charm and deceit. For the first time in weeks, Lucian allowed himself a flicker of satisfactionâ€”his hunger quieted, his purpose clear.Allies Strengthened: Evelyn Crowe: reaffirmed loyalty through compassion and practical counsel. Adrian Vale: elevated to true confidant and researcher within Lucianâ€™s private circle. Mysteries Deepened: Lucianâ€™s signature predates his memoryâ€”his Embrace and the Pactâ€™s founding are linked. Marianneâ€™s death was deliberate, a possible attempt to break the Rosethornâ€™s hold. The Pactâ€™s influence appears to bind its members across centuries. Lucianâ€™s Standing: Renewed his confidence and artistry through creation. Now aware he may be a keystone within the Rosethornâ€™s structure. Preparing to confront both Prince Welles and Sir Reginald Harkerâ€”each believing him loyal. item.title: Lucian Valemont
item.description:
#Character
Infobox
Prince Adrian Welles's personal seal of protection
Sir Reginald Harker 's token of appreciation: A black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.** Mortal Life (1850s â€“ 1870s)
Born in the soot and smog of Londonâ€™s East End, Lucien was a servant boy in a manor belonging to Lord Adrien Valemont, an eccentric nobleman known for his scandalous soirÃ©es and obsession with art, mysticism, and the beautiful decay of the flesh. Lucien was quiet, sharp-eyed, and gifted â€” a boy who sketched his masters and their guests by candlelight, capturing their vanity and despair in equal measure.One night, his sketches were discovered. Instead of punishment, Lucien was summoned. Lord Valemont saw in him something exquisite â€” a living muse, a sculpture of hunger and grace yet unformed.The Embrace The Lord grew infatuated, blurring the lines between patron, artist, and lover. When Lucien reached his twenty-first year, Valemont whispered, â€œYou are too perfect to fade.â€ That night, Lucien died upon satin sheets and awoke into the Requiem â€” reborn by his masterâ€™s hand, not as a man, but as a masterpiece.Valemont shaped him as one might a statue: taught him the arts, the poise, the secrets of blood and brush. Yet like all art, Lucien outgrew his maker. Over decades, he came to see Valemontâ€™s love as possession â€” beauty caged, desire gilded.In 1910, during the fire that consumed the Valemont Estate, Lucien disappeared into the night. The ashes of his master were found in the marble gallery, a smile painted upon his lips.Modern Nights (Present) Now, Lucien Valemont lives again â€” an immortal aesthete in the modern age, a â€œmodern Rasputinâ€ whose salons blur the line between enlightenment and ecstasy. His haven, The Crimson Salon, is an opulent labyrinth of books, art, and pleasure. Mortals and Kindred alike gather there â€” poets, occultists, models, sinners â€” all drawn to Lucienâ€™s promise: â€œTo be remembered is to be eternal. Come, and let me paint your soul.â€ He curates his collection of forbidden books and occult tomes, forever chasing the same question that haunted his sire â€” can art transcend death, or must it consume life to do so?ğŸŒ¹ Lucien Valemont, Caretaker of the RosethornClan: Toreador Sire: Lord Adrien Valemont (deceased) Title: The Caretaker of the Heart Current Domain: Harker Estate, London Chronicle: Velvet Veil â€“ The Thorns Beneath the RoseğŸ•¯ï¸ Current StatusFollowing the death of Sir Reginald Harker and the revelations surrounding the Rosethorn Pact, Lucien Valemont assumed guardianship of the Heart and the Roses Below â€” the pulsing, vitae-fed roots that bind the covenantâ€™s original oath.He does not command their power; instead, he tends to it â€” a penitent keeper, chosen (or cursed) to ensure the roses never fall into the hands of those who would misuse them.Each night, Lucien walks the catacombs beneath the estate â€” a labyrinth of brick and bone where roses bloom from walls slick with vitae.To keep them alive, he must feed them: sacrifices offered in silence, The roses whisper to him, echoing the voices of those consumed â€” his court of ghosts and blossoms.He paints their faces to remember them.ğŸ©¸ The PenanceAt the Princeâ€™s command, Lucien accepted a Penance Eternal. His art must now be service, his beauty a burden.In secret, he disobeys only one part of that vow: he keeps the painting â€” The Heart Beneath the Rose â€” sealed within the Velvet Veil. He tells no one that it still breathes.ğŸŒ¹ The Rosethornâ€™s NatureThe Heart is not a metaphor. It is literal â€” a fleshy mass of vitae and root, the remnant of the First Toreadorâ€™s Heart, interwoven with thorns, pulsing faintly in the dark. The Roses bloom from it, white as wax, red at the tips. They thirst. They remember. They sing.Lucienâ€™s duty is to keep their song quiet â€” and their hunger sated.ğŸ©¸ The Penance of the RosesTo keep the roses alive, Lucien must feed them life itself. The roots beneath the Harker Estate crave breath, warmth, and the pulse of a living heart.In the catacombs below, iron reliquaries line the walls , shaped like sarcophagi, grim devices from another age, waiting in the depths beneath the Harker Estate. Within them, the vines twist and bloom, feeding not from the ground but from the warmth of the living. Those brought below are never seen again; their bodies vanish into the growth, leaving only faint echoes of voices that murmur through the petals at night.Lucien did not build them. They were already there when he inherited the duty; remnants of an ancient design meant to sustain the Heart below. He merely continues the ritual, because without it the roses would wither, and the Heart he protects would perish with them.Each offering is chosen carefully, sometimes drawn by his charm, sometimes by promise, sometimes by fate. When the hour comes, Lucien descends alone. He does not flee or turn away. He waits in the silence of the chamber, head bowed, until the last whisper fades and the roses have taken what they require. It is not cruelty that holds him there but contrition; a penance willingly endured.He paints each face afterwards, records each name. The portraits line the walls of the Velvet Veil, mute witnesses to the price of preservation. Every stroke of pigment reminds him that beauty demands blood, and that love; the kind that feeds the Pact; is always a cage.

London, 2002 â€” the cityâ€™s Kindred society thrives under the shadow of Prince Adrian Welles. The nights are filled with rain, cigarette smoke, and the slow decay of the old order.
Lucian, a Toreador of Victorian origin and keeper of an archive called The Velvet Veil, receives a summons from his former lover and now Prince, Adrian Welles. The courtâ€™s Harpy, Marianne of Bath, has been found staked in her haven. Whispers of treachery ripple through Elysium.
Lucian arrives at the National Gallery, where Wellesâ€™ court holds vigil. Seneschal Elodie Rains greets him coldly, testing his composure. He deflects her probing questions about Marianneâ€™s death with charm and wit, drawing admiration and suspicion alike.
In the shadows, Lucian meets his Nosferatu contact, Grimshaw. The sewer-borne informant reveals that Marianneâ€™s last meeting wasnâ€™t with a Brujah revolutionary in Whitechapel â€” but with Sir Reginald Harker, Keeper of Elysium, in Knightsbridge.
Grimshaw passes Lucian a bloodstained notebook recovered from Marianneâ€™s haven. Inside, one phrase repeats: â€œThe Rosethorn Pactâ€Lucian presents the notebook to Prince Welles in private, masking his fear with devotion. The Prince is intrigued, remembering the name Rosethorn from decades past. He tasks Lucian to quietly watch for any sign of the Pact, entrusting him with his personal seal of protection and warning him that Harker will not take kindly to such knowledge.Lucian leaves the Princeâ€™s alcove under the watchful eyes of the court â€” and Harker himself.
Lucian accepts Harkerâ€™s invitation to a secluded lounge within Elysium. What follows is a conversation laced with manipulation, attraction, and power. Lucian submits outwardly, using intimacy as his weapon. Harker probes for information about what Lucian told the Prince; Lucian gives him only fragments and half-truths.When the meeting ends, Harker leaves behind a token â€” a black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.Grimshaw later identifies it as a mark of belonging to the Rosethorn Pact â€” a symbol worn by Marianne before her death. Lucian understands the implication: heâ€™s now publicly claimed as one of Harkerâ€™s possessions.
Lucian returns home through the wet streets of Camden. The rain on the windowpanes echoes the rhythm of his heartbeat. He stands before his mirror, staring at the rose on his lapel â€” both collar and key.He realizes the truth of his position: He must serve two masters â€” the Prince who once loved him and the Keeper who now owns him â€” while walking the razor edge between their secrets.As the city hums below, Lucian swears to himself that heâ€™ll play both sides until he can cut the strings from them all.Allies:
Prince Adrian Welles: trusts Lucian; granted him personal protection.
Grimshaw (Nosferatu): wary but loyal informant; manages secret communications. Enemies / Dangers:
Sir Reginald Harker: Keeper of Elysium, possible member of Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact; now considers Lucian his marked â€œproperty.â€
Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact: unknown purpose; connected to Marianneâ€™s murder and Kindred influence in Londonâ€™s elite. Lucianâ€™s Standing: Elevated status with the Prince. Dangerous attachment to Harker. Knowledge of a secret society that could destabilize Londonâ€™s Camarilla.

VTM V5 â€“ Session 2: â€œThe Thorns of Memoryâ€Chronicle: Velvet Veil Coterie Member: Lucian Valemont (Toreador) Setting: London, modern nightSession Summary
The session opened with Lucian awakening in The Velvet Veil, hunger gnawing after a sleepless day haunted by memories of the previous nightâ€™s encounter with Grimshaw and the word Rosethorn. His ghoul, Evelyn, brought him news of a deliveryâ€”an intended vessel for his hungerâ€”but Lucian, weary of mind and spirit, refused to feed on a stranger. The act of restraint foreshadowed the moral and emotional conflict that would define the night.
Later, a willing donorâ€” Adrian Vale, the Student, one of Lucianâ€™s regularsâ€”was brought to the library. Their interaction began as an intellectual exchange on Victorian vampiric myth and ended as a dark reflection of Lucianâ€™s own past, as he revealed himself and fed. The feeding was intimate but controlled, reaffirming his humanity rather than eroding it. The Student, enthralled and awed, became Lucianâ€™s new ghoul, marked with his personal sigil.Afterward, Lucian painted the youth as he sleptâ€”an act of creation and sin intertwinedâ€”and sealed his hunger in colour and canvas.
The following evening, Lucian descended into Londonâ€™s museum sub-basement, where he met Dr. Sebastian Crowe, the Curator of The Victoria & Albert Museum and recovered The Rosethorn Folio, a set of three vellum pages bearing the signatures of long-dead (and still-undead) aristocrats, including his own and that of his former master, Sir Reginald Harker. The tense exchange was interrupted by the arrival of Elias Crane, an agent of Harkerâ€™s, resulting in a standoff of old powers. Through cunning and the invocation of his lineage, Lucian claimed legal and personal ownership of the artefact.
Back home, he faced Sir Reginald himself, whose visit turned into a familiar but fraught power game. Their relationshipâ€”part devotion, part manipulationâ€”culminated in a reminder of the elderâ€™s control and a warning about the Rosethornâ€™s origins. Reginald revealed that the Lady Marianne of Bath, one of the covenantâ€™s founders, had died by her own will, seeking to sever the blood-bonded pact that still haunts them all.Lucian did not believe him.
Drained but resolute, Lucian fed lightly from Evelyn in a moment of hunger and remorse, reaffirming his humanity with his restraint and affection. The session closed with a meeting between Lucian and Prince Adrien, his oldest friend and the ruler of Londonâ€™s Kindred. Adrien, aware of the Rosethornâ€™s resurfacing, demanded Lucianâ€™s loyaltyâ€”but the two shared a rare, honest exchange about their friendship, their vows, and the ghosts of their shared past.Lucian left the Princeâ€™s office torn between duty to his ruler and an older, darker allegiance bound in blood and secrecy.Key Outcomes
The Rosethorn Folio Acquired: The ancient document listing the founding members of the covenant, including Lucian, Reginald, and the late Lady Marianne of Bath, now rests in Lucianâ€™s personal vault.
New Ghoul Created: The Student, Adrian Vale, is now bound to Lucian and branded with his sign.Sir Reginaldâ€™s Influence Reignited: Reginaldâ€™s manipulation and warnings hint at deeper conspiracies within the covenant.Prince Adrien Informed: Adrien is aware of the folioâ€™s existence but not its contents. He trusts Lucianâ€”for now.Humanity Check Passed: Despite predatory acts, Lucianâ€™s remorse and tenderness preserved his soul.
Political Stakes Raised: The Rosethorn Pact threatens to expose a web of blood oaths among Londonâ€™s elite Kindred.Session Tone & ThemesGothic decadence and moral decayLove versus loyaltyArt as confessionPredation intertwined with tendernessThe weight of immortal memory
