Candlelight flickers against oil paintings â€” Rembrandt, Turner, Rossetti â€” while Kindred mingle in murmurs and false smiles.Prince Adrian stands near the dais, his pale hand resting on a silver-topped cane. The Seneschal, a Ventrue named Elodie Rains, approaches you first, her gaze like polished glass. Elodie: â€œLucian. You grace us at last. The Prince will be most eager to hear yourâ€¦ aesthetic insights. But between us â€” what did Marianne tell you before she perished? You two wereâ€¦ familiar.â€ Sheâ€™s probing. In public. A test of composure and loyalty."My lady Rains.." Lucian made an elegant overexagerated bow, wearing a fine open tunic shirt in the Neuve noir style, open neck and frills. tight leather trousers and knee high boots."It is a heartbreak the moment I heard that Lady Marianne was... you know.." He made a steaking motion into his chest. "First of all, I have not spoken to her in a few months."Elodie Rains watches your performance with an expression that doesnâ€™t quite reach her eyes. The Seneschalâ€™s lips twitch â€” not a smile, but the ghost of one. Around you, the chatter of Kindred grows hushed; a few Toreador hang on your words like admirers at a salon performance. Elodie: â€œMm. I see your flair for drama remains intact.â€ She takes a step closer, voice a whisper meant for you alone. â€œCareful, Lucian. The Prince isâ€¦ disturbed by her death. And he has already tasked the Hounds with finding her killer. If he suspects your silence hides something, it will not end with words.â€ She brushes past, perfume faint and cold. You can feel her intent â€” she wanted to warn youâ€¦ or perhaps to see how you react when cornered.At that moment, someone else approaches: A short man in a dark velvet coat, hair slicked back like oil â€” Grimshaw, your Nosferatu contact. He gives a subtle bow, eyes darting toward a quiet corner behind a sculpture of St. Michael. Grimshaw (low voice): â€œGot something for you, Luci. Marianneâ€™s last meeting wasnâ€™t in Whitechapel like everyone says. It was in Knightsbridge. And she wasnâ€™t with a Brujah â€” she was meeting someone from Elysium.â€ He pauses, a grin splitting his sallow face. â€œGuess who.â€ Lucian looks a little offended at Elodie as he puts his hand on his chest. "My lady, you wound me with those accusations. I am a loyal servent of the Prince and the Camarilla since my introduction all those years ago. I have done nothing but be honest and open with all who come to me and those who summon me." He nodded softly.Turning to Grimshaw, Lucian nodded and motioned. "As you see, I have pulled favours to find out what had happened, Although Whitechapel is a horrible place, Knightsbridge even more so..." He turned to the contact. "Who?"Lovelyâ€”Lucianâ€™s injured dignity plays like music through the hall. The surrounding Kindred murmur with subtle appreciation; even Elodie seems momentarily disarmed by his gallant tone. She offers only a curt nod before drifting off to attend to another guest.Now the spotlight narrows to you and Grimshaw, tucked behind the sculptureâ€™s marble wings. The low buzz of the salon becomes a distant hum, the scent of candlewax and aged wine hanging between you.Grimshawâ€™s eyes dart left and right before he speaks, his voice a conspiratorial rasp. Grimshaw: â€œMarianne met with Sir Reginald Harker. You know himâ€”Keeper of Elysium, Toreador like yourself, all white gloves and quiet cruelty. The Prince trusts him more than anyone. Or used to.â€ He produces a thin, leather-bound notebook, small enough to hide in a sleeve. The edges are stained with something dark. â€œFound this in Marianneâ€™s haven. Mentions The Rosethorn Pact. Donâ€™t know what that is yet, but whatever she learned got her killed.â€ He glances toward the Princeâ€™s dais. â€œYou tell Welles, and heâ€™ll tear Elysium apart looking for scapegoats. You tell Harker, and heâ€™ll bury you under a dozen compliments and call it art. My advice? Keep your head low until you know which oneâ€™s the spider.â€ He pauses, half-grinning. â€œUnless youâ€™re feeling brave, Luci.â€ "Well dont you have my balls in a vice my little impish friend." he sighed, running his hand down his face, before approaching the Prince, more pomp and elegance as he bowedLucianâ€™s boots click softly on the marble as he strides through the candlelit gallery. The gathered Kindred part like curtains, watching with a mix of envy and dread as he approaches the dais.Prince Adrian Welles stands before Turnerâ€™s â€œThe Fighting Temeraireâ€, the faint glow of its golden horizon reflected in his pale eyes. A beautiful corpse admiring another. His voice, when he speaks, is gentle â€” too gentle. Welles: â€œLucian. The rose among brambles.â€ He turns, a faint smile ghosting his lips. â€œMarianneâ€™s death wounds us all. You were close to her. Tell meâ€¦ do you mourn her as I do?â€ He gestures for you to rise. The Seneschal, Elodie, lingers just out of earshot â€” clearly watching.Now is your moment. You can present the notebook and shape the narrative."She will be missed, my Prince. I was fond of her, she had an air and perfume that I much enjoyed being around. Plus, her tits were to die for." He chuckled softly to himself."I... I am torn my Prince. A contact of mine whom I sent to investigate upon hearing the act, found something that would put me at a disadvantage to all sides. I fear for my safety, not from you my Prince, you are as ever, a graceful and honrouable patron.. " He bowed again. "But I am fearful of those who did this to our dearest Marianne. If I may, I wish to approach and bring this to your attention, without the prying eyes of those around."The humor cuts through the tension like a fine edge â€” daring, irreverent, Toreador to the bone. The Princeâ€™s expression doesnâ€™t change at first, but a corner of his mouth betrays the faintest ghost of amusement. A ripple of whispers passes through the court â€” Lucian always did dance on knives.Welles raises a pale hand, and immediately, the chatter dies. The room grows so silent you can hear the rain tapping against the galleryâ€™s grand windows. Welles: â€œVery well, Lucian. Let us step aside.â€ His voice is soft but heavy, carrying the kind of command that brooks no refusal. He gestures toward a curtained alcove â€” a private annex lined with portraits of mortal nobles long dead. Once inside, the velvet curtains close behind you, muting the outside world. The Prince turns, his eyes sharp now, the veneer of charm fading into something ancient. Welles: â€œShow me.â€ You remove the notebook, holding it delicately as if it might crumble. Its worn leather glints in the flickering light.The Prince accepts it carefully, opening to the page marked by a torn ribbon â€” The Rosethorn Pact. His brows knit slightly. Welles: â€œThisâ€¦ name. I have not heard it in decades.â€ He looks up, meeting your gaze. â€œYou were wise to bring this to me. But tell me â€” who gave you this?â€ You feel the weight of the question. His voice is calm, but thereâ€™s an edge, like the hush before a predatorâ€™s lunge. Grimshawâ€™s name burns at the back of your throat â€” valuable, but dangerous."A contact of mine found it in her belongings.. He is, well.. not one for the glamour of the light. If you catch my drift..."Welles studies you for several long seconds. The candlelight catches his eyes â€” ancient, cold, and strangelyâ€¦ amused. Welles: â€œAh. The shadows speak to you, then.â€ He closes the notebook slowly, fingers tapping its cover as if testing the rhythm of a waltz. â€œThat pleases me. The Camarilla needs those who listen to whispers, not those who shout them.â€ He takes a half-step closer, lowering his voice to something confidential â€” almost intimate. Welles: â€œYou have done well, Lucian. If this Rosethorn Pact stirs again, I want you to be my eyes and my voice in that dark. Bring me what you find. Quietly.â€ â€œIn returnâ€¦â€ he glances toward the curtain, where Elodie waits like a statue, â€œâ€¦I will see that you are protected from whatever wolves stalk this court.â€ He places the notebook into his coat. The moment feels sealed, heavy with unseen consequence.Then, with the faintest smile: Welles: â€œTell me, my rose â€” do you trust Sir Reginald Harker?â€ You realize this is not idle curiosity. The Prince is measuring you. He knows youâ€™ve already considered the possibility.This is the pivotal point â€” your words will shape how Welles moves next: whether Harker becomes an ally, an enemy, or a target.He pauses, thinking for a moment."I have not had the pleasure of his courtie but I have heard about him. And the rumours in the circles of his actions. I honestly have no opinion on him as of yet my Prince."Welles regards you for a long moment, his stillness unnerving. Then, slowly, the Princeâ€™s expression softens â€” the faintest curl of a satisfied smile. Welles: â€œSpoken like a true servant of the Camarilla. A man of reason amid a sea of passion.â€ He steps closer, lowering his tone so only you can hear. â€œHold to that composure, Lucian. The nights ahead will tempt you to passion â€” and in passion, the Toreador are at their weakest.â€ He reaches into his coat and produces a small, folded card of thick, cream parchment. The Princeâ€™s personal seal â€” black wax embossed with a rose and crown. Welles: â€œTake this. Present it to my Herald should you require sanctuary, or should anyone question your place in this court. You have done me a service tonight.â€ He looks toward the curtain. â€œNow go, my rose. Enjoy the music. And keep your eyes open. Harker will not rest easy when he learns his name passed through your lips â€” even so gently.â€ With that, he turns away, leaving you with the faint scent of sandalwood and old paper.Back in the main hall, the atmosphere has shifted â€” murmurs ripple through the gathered Kindred. You notice Sir Reginald Harker himself standing by the piano, surrounded by lesser Toreador. He raises a glass of dark vitae toward you, a sly smile touching his lips.Youâ€™ve barely taken three steps when Grimshaw sidles back up beside you, whispering low: Grimshaw: â€œYou did it, didnâ€™t you? Whatever you said, the Princeâ€™s pet ghoul just left Elysium in a hurry. Looks like someoneâ€™s about to get visited.â€ He smirks. â€œSo, what now, Luci? You going to let the old manâ€™s hounds handle it, or dig deeper yourself before the trailâ€™s cold?â€ Taking his hand as the card is handed, Lucian kisses it gently; a loving kiss. A submissive kiss. One that had been shared many years ago on warm nights with a fledgling soon to be Prince and the artist before him."Yes my Prince. "returning, he takes a glass of blood and downs it in one, not able to even take the time to savour it. Raising the empty glass to Sir Reginald.Looking to grimshaw, he sighs."I'm going to do what my Prince requires. I am going into the den of lions as a little lamb. I know sir Reginald has a thing for those of my... appearance and virvor.. We will bed, and we will talk against the pillow, as all do."Grimshaw huffs out a low, wet laugh â€” the sound of a gutter-born man genuinely impressed. Grimshaw: â€œYou mad, shining bastard. Youâ€™re going to let the spider wrap you up and call it art.â€ He glances around, lowers his voice. â€œFine. Iâ€™ll keep an ear to the sewers. If the hounds start sniffinâ€™ too close, Iâ€™ll send word. You justâ€¦ donâ€™t get eaten.â€ He melts back into the crowd, swallowed by marble and shadow.You make your way across the gallery. Harker is waiting â€” immaculate as a statue, one hand resting on a cane thatâ€™s more ornament than support. His gaze follows you, appreciative in the way collectors study paintings they already own. Harker: â€œLucian. The Princeâ€™s favorite pet graces my corner. Youâ€™ve been avoiding me, havenâ€™t you? I do hope itâ€™s not fear.â€ He steps closer, voice dropping to a purr. Harker: â€œYou lookâ€¦ exquisite tonight. Come â€” drink with me. I insist.â€ He gestures toward a secluded lounge where the candles burn lower and the whispers sound like sighs. The table glitters with crystal and silver, and the air smells faintly of rosewater and blood.You sit. The dance begins.Harker leans forward, eyes glittering. Harker: â€œThey say you brought something interesting to our Prince. You wouldnâ€™t happen to know what that might be, would you?â€ He smiles, thin and knowing â€” the smile of a man who already suspects, and is waiting to see how gracefully you lie."No far at all My Lord Sire." Lucian bows and curtsies. Taking his hand and kissing it softly."I've just been so gathered with so much work in the painters alley that I've been unable to be torn away from the muses." He chuckled softly. The tone, the voice, the purr, the sly hand slipped down the back of his trousers to prod his opening with a single finger..Intent, he all but knew."Ofcourse my lord sire.. I wouldn't think of anything I'd want to do more." He gasped softly, following him into the lounge and sitting beside him.Leg crossed, one hanging over Harker's leg, Lucian pressed up against Harker, he spoke softly, playing with the older's hair with an eblow on the sofa back behind him."There was the death of one of a close friends of ours... he asked if I knew anything. An old contact of mine brought me a letter he found, to some Nosferatu working for the Anarchists..." He lied, half lied."The Prince is going to search there way." He sighed, a needy husky submissive sigh as he sipped the blood in the wine glassThe lounge feels smaller than it is. The air is perfumed with dust, velvet, and vitae. Harker allows the nearness â€” even encourages it â€” a faint smirk curling his mouth as Lucianâ€™s charm bleeds into the moment. For the Toreador, proximity is conversation; the body is punctuation. Harker: â€œAhâ€¦ the muses. They are such jealous lovers.â€ His fingers trace the rim of his glass. â€œYou do them justice, Lucian. Even your lies are painted beautifully.â€ He tilts his head, eyes narrowing in faint amusement. Harker: â€œSo the Prince sends his hounds to the sewers. Convenient. Keeps his gaze away from the gallery, doesnâ€™t it?â€ A pause. The mask slips â€” just a flicker, but Lucian sees it: the tiniest tightening of the jaw, a ripple of irritation that he hides behind a smile. Harker: â€œTell me, my dear, did yourâ€¦ contact happen to mention what this letter said? Or did you leave that part out to make me chase it from your lips?â€ The question is bait. You can feel it. Heâ€™s not sure what you know â€” but heâ€™s fishing, testing whether the Prince told you anything real. The wine-dark candlelight glints across his signet ring â€” engraved with a thorned rose.With their lips almost close, faces so close as if to kiss, but not... The two sat there, Lucian pressed against him like a good submissive toy."I did not read it. The Prince's dog summoned me. I dont get involved in the court's dealings. I am just an archivist, collector, painter and... lover.."The line lands softly, but it hits its mark. Harkerâ€™s eyes stay on yours a long moment â€” weighing, measuring, wondering whether to believe the meekness or enjoy it. He lets the pause stretch until it hums. Harker: â€œA loverâ€¦ and yet, you find yourself in the centre of a Princeâ€™s investigation.â€ He smiles faintly. â€œThat, my dear Lucian, is why I adore artists. You pretend not to play the game, and still, you always end up on the stage.â€ He straightens, the air cooling between you. The mask returns, voice smooth once more. Harker: â€œKeep to your paints for now. If His Grace asks, tell him that I am as loyal as ever. You may even tell him I toasted to Marianneâ€™s memory tonight.â€ His smile doesnâ€™t reach his eyes. â€œAnd if the Rosethorn nonsense resurfaces again, come to me first. We mustnâ€™t trouble the Prince with rumours.â€ He stands, adjusts his cuffs, then glances back down at you. Harker: â€œYou wear obedience beautifully, Lucian. But rememberâ€”submission can be a kind of art, too. Practise it wisely.â€ He leaves you in the low light, the sound of the chamber orchestra drifting faintly from the gallery beyond. On the table beside his half-empty glass lies something he must have meant you to notice: a small pressed rose, its petals darkened to near black and pricked through with a silver pin.Grimshaw appears a few minutes later, lurking in the doorway, eyes darting between you and the abandoned flower. Grimshaw: â€œWell? You live. Thatâ€™s somethinâ€™. Whatâ€™s that he left ya?â€ Hearing the Rosethorn word, he almost coughed at it, but kept his face submissivly passive."Ofcourse.. my lord sire.." He said softly, slowly sliding down the sofa until he was on his knee's between the Lord's legs. A sharp nailed hand running through his silvery white hair.Fade to blackAfter Harker had left the alchove; Lucian sprawled on the leather sofa in the quiet slcohove, Using a paper fan to cool himself down, "Shut up you disgusting rat." Lucian's mask dropped for once. He picked up the glass rose, inspecting it close as he pinned it to his lapel."Its a whore bitches collar. To tell the world who's bitch I am." He growled. "What do you want.."You can almost hear the gallery again now that Harkerâ€™s presence is goneâ€”the faint scrape of a bow across strings, the hush of other conversations resuming once the Princeâ€™s Keeper has taken his leave.Grimshaw steps a little further inside. Heâ€™s still smiling, but itâ€™s the kind of grin that hides nerves rather than delight. Grimshaw: â€œEasy, Luci. You still got both eyes and a heartbeatâ€”undead as it is. Thatâ€™s a win in my book.â€ He gestures with a stubby finger toward the pinned rose. Grimshaw: â€œThat thingâ€™s got teeth, though. You feel it? Thereâ€™s a symbol etched on the pinâ€”tiny, under the clasp. Old sigil the Nosferatu trade around; it means property of the Rosethorn. Marianne had one in her haven too, same metal. Whoever wears itâ€™s marked as belonging to the Pact, or claimed by it.â€ He crouches beside the couch, voice dropping lower. Grimshaw: â€œYou just got drafted into their little club, whether you like it or not. Question is: you gonna wear the leash and see where it leads, or cut it off before they start tugging?â€ He straightens, waiting, his expression halfway between admiration and worry."The man just fucked me, used me and told me in no uncertain terms I'm his bitch, and that he is involved. THIS is exactly what you said it is. And its not your business to know what I do with it." He growled. "And you'll probably sell this information to anyone who asks or pays you enough." He sighed, standing up, pulling up his trousers and fastening his belt, brushing his fingers through his hair and checking his stained self in the reflection of a nearby picture frame."The Prince was a brother to me, a lover, one of my closest companions. I serve him, but this.." He flicked the rose. "Is all part of serving my Prince. I have to play both sides."Grimshaw lifts both hands, palms out, the smirk fading. Grimshaw: â€œEasy, easy. You donâ€™t owe me your soul, Luci. Youâ€™re rightâ€”I deal in whispers, not faith. But I ainâ€™t stupid enough to sell a rumour thatâ€™s got the Prince and Harker both stitched into it.â€ He waits while you straighten yourself, eyes flicking toward the curtained doorway. Grimshaw: â€œAll right. You play the pretty pawn. Just remember pawns bleed first when the board flips.â€ He hesitates, then adds quietly: Grimshaw: â€œIf you need to pass something to Welles without anyone seeinâ€™ you together, leave it at the old tube station in Camden Town. The one they never reopened after the Blitz. Iâ€™ll make sure it reaches him.â€ He melts back toward the shadows, voice dropping to a rasp. Grimshaw: â€œWatch Harkerâ€™s temper. The man collects people the way you collect paintings. And when he gets boredâ€¦â€ The rest is lost in the din of the gallery as he disappears.Lucian is alone again. The faint strings of the orchestra drift through the curtains. Outside this little alcove, the Elysiumâ€™s glittering court has resumed its danceâ€”none of them yet realising that the game has changed.The rose on your lapel catches the light, a small glint of silver and black.Youâ€™ve gained: The Princeâ€™s favour â€” protection and access. Harkerâ€™s mark â€” leverage and danger. Grimshawâ€™s channel â€” a way to move in the dark unseen. He threw the empty glass at the cloth curtain covering the door to get Grimshaw to leave.With a sigh, he goes home.The glass hits the curtain with a sharp, hollow clink, rolls across the marble, and disappears into the folds. The sound is enough; you hear Grimshawâ€™s boots scuff once, then fade completely.Outside, Londonâ€™s rain has turned from mist to a steady downpour. The streets are slick mirrors of sodium light. By the time Lucian reaches his building in Camden, the night smells of wet stone and paint thinner â€” the scent of his own exile.Inside, The Velvet Veil waits just as he left it: canvases leaning against walls, half-finished studies of faces he canâ€™t quite forget. The only sound is the soft ticking of an antique clock and the occasional sigh of pipes behind the plaster.He peels off the damp shirt, hangs the coat where it always hangs. The rose glints faintly in the mirror, the tiny silver pin catching the roomâ€™s lone bulb. A reminder. A claim.For a moment, Lucianâ€™s reflection looks like the boy who once knelt before a fledgling artist turned Prince, full of hope and devotion. Then the illusion breaks, leaving only the pale creature with too many debts and not enough time to pay them.He pours himself another glass, this time not pretending to taste it. The city hums below â€” its heartbeat slow and secret. Allies: Prince Adrian Welles â€” trusts you, for now. You hold his personal seal. Grimshaw (Nosferatu) â€” wary ally, courier of secrets. Enemies / Dangers: Sir Reginald Harker â€” Keeper of Elysium, probable member of the Rosethorn Pact. Has â€œmarkedâ€ you as his. The Rosethorn Pact â€” unknown purpose, tied to Marianneâ€™s death. Current Status: You are walking a double line between the Prince and Harker. The mark makes you both protected and exposed. Knightsbridge remains the last confirmed site connected to the Pact.

item.description:
User: Lewis Stockton (lewisstocktonnovelist@gmail.com) Created: 10/22/2025 19:59:07 Updated: 10/29/2025 14:43:04 Exported: 10/29/2025 15:20:59
Link: https://chatgpt.com/g/g-p-68f8e02854848191a44040ad3410196a/c/68f92979-cafc-8332-b01d-c4f21384db14 Let's do the next session of vtm v5Perfect. Before we start â€” letâ€™s quickly align so I can set the tone right.Can you confirm these details for me: Which character(s) youâ€™re playing this session? (Lucien Valemont, or others?) Where we left off â€” last I saw, Lucien had just left after that tense scene with Grimshaw and the mention of the Rosethorn and the Prince. Do you want to pick up immediately after that, or skip ahead (e.g., to his haven or next night)? Are we keeping this in the same chronicle continuity â€” the Velvet Veil haven, the Prince, Grimshaw, etc.? Once Iâ€™ve got that, Iâ€™ll set the scene and weâ€™ll dive straight into Session 2.I'm Lucian. Also when doing the responses. Leave it open for me to do my actions. Don't suggest actions. And don't take thr plot too far. We need to go.deeper not wider in scopeWe skip to the next night using the rules of the tabletopPerfect â€” understood completely. Iâ€™ll handle narration, NPC dialogue, and environment only. Youâ€™ll handle Lucienâ€™s thoughts, words, and actions. Iâ€™ll move time using V5 structure: End of night â†’ Hunger roll â†’ Rouse checks â†’ New night begins. Weâ€™ll keep this tight, focused, and deep in tone and character.Session 2: The Night AfterThe world turns dark again. The sun dies over London, and the city exhales smoke, perfume, and sin. Lucien Valemont stirs. Before we begin, we perform the Rouse Check for awakening.Roll one die (or I can roll it for you): Success (6+) â†’ You do not gain Hunger. Fail (1â€“5) â†’ You gain +1 Hunger. Would you like me to roll for you, or do you want to roll your own?So the rollAlright â€” rolling one die for Lucienâ€™s Rouse Check as he awakensâ€¦ ğŸ²Result: 4Thatâ€™s a fail â€” you awaken hungrier than before. Hunger increases by +1. The Velvet Veil is silent when your eyes open. Velvet curtains hang heavy, the faint scent of blood and old wine mingling in the still air. Somewhere beyond the walls, the muffled hum of London nightlife seeps through â€” laughter, sirens, the pulse of the city.Your phone, resting on the antique vanity, blinks once. A message received just moments ago.Would you like to check it? Or attend to something else first?With a sigh. Lucian woke. Tires. Hungry. He'd not fed when he got home, the thoughts, memories and act with the man raged in his mind.Sitting in the edge of his bed. He rubbed his face. One of his servants should be about. Not a real servant but a ghoul he protected and was part of his littke inner circle.Pressing the phone button, he stood up and stretchedThe screenâ€™s glow paints the room in cold blue light.1 New Message â€” from: Evelyn â€œGood evening, sir. Iâ€™ve brought what you asked for. Sheâ€™s downstairs in the parlor. Breathing, clean, and terrified. Shall I send her up?â€ You can hear faint footsteps somewhere below, the creak of floorboards near the stairwell â€” the rhythm of the living pacing nervously.The hunger inside stirs, whispering against restraint. Even the stretch of your limbs feels slow, deliberate, predatory.The room remains still â€” velvet curtains drawn tight, candlelight guttering in the reflection of a gilded mirror.What does Lucien do?He clicked the speaker button. "Who. What? Why?" He groanedThereâ€™s a short pause â€” then Evelynâ€™s voice comes through the tinny speaker, her tone careful, measured, deferential. â€œYou said last week, sirâ€¦ to keep one on hand. For when you wake like this.â€ â€œA dancer from one of the clubs you like. No drugs, no disease. I screened her myself.â€ A faint sound of movement filters through the phone â€” Evelyn lowering her voice. â€œShe doesnâ€™t know what you are. Just thinks itâ€™s a private appointment. Shall I bring her up, orâ€¦ dispose of her?â€ The words dispose of hang heavy, like perfume in still air. Somewhere in the hallway outside, the soft hum of the building continues â€” life, waiting.What does Lucien say?"Tell her I am sorry she was disturbed. Give her money and a call a cab for her. Pay for it." He sighed.You can almost hear Evelyn hesitate before replying â€” a soft intake of breath, a whisper caught between obedience and concern. â€œ...Understood, sir.â€ A pause. Then, quieter, with that faint tremor of familiarity only a ghoul whoâ€™s seen too much would dare show: â€œYou should feed soon, Lucien. You know what happens if you wait too long.â€ The line clicks dead.Below, faint footsteps move across the wooden floor, a murmured conversation, the sound of a door opening and closing â€” then the low rumble of a cab engine outside fading into the distance.The Velvet Veil is silent again. Only you and the echo of your own restraint remain.The hunger gnaws â€” itâ€™s not unbearable yet, but the beast in you stirs, restless and listening.A moment later, a soft knock on your chamber door. Evelynâ€™s voice, subdued but professional: â€œSheâ€™s gone. Coffeeâ€™s on your desk. Synthetic. I thought it might help.â€ What does Lucien do?(Don't keep asking what I do)"Thank you eve.. I'm.. I'm sorry. It was a horrible session in court. I am drained.. muse and physically"The door opens a fraction â€” just enough for Evelyn to slip in. Sheâ€™s dressed in her usual sharp, understated black, a silver chain glinting faintly against her throat â€” the one you gave her, long ago.She sets the steaming cup down on your desk without a word, her expression softening as she studies you. â€œYou donâ€™t need to explain, sir.â€ â€œYou come back from those meetings looking like death itself â€” more than usual.â€ Her attempt at humor dies halfway out of her mouth. She folds her hands in front of her, eyes lowered. â€œDo you want me to cancel the curatorâ€™s appointment tomorrow? The one about the Rosethorn piece?â€ Her tone is light, but the name carries weight â€” unspoken implications between you both.He looked up quickly. "The what?" He stood up, right in her face all.of a sudden. "What did you say?"Evelyn stiffens as your movement cuts through the air â€” her pulse audibly quickens, a flutter beneath the scent of perfume and fear. She doesnâ€™t step back, but her voice lowers. â€œThe Rosethorn, sir. The curator from the British Museumâ€”he said youâ€™d arranged to meet about an acquisition, some manuscript fragment connected to it. He confirmed it yesterday. I thought you knew.â€ Her throat moves as she swallows, trying to hold your gaze. â€œShould Iâ€¦ tell him youâ€™re indisposed?â€ The word Rosethorn seems to hang in the air now â€” almost alive, like a whispered invocation that stirs the Beast just behind your ribs. The hunger sharpens, curious, remembering last nightâ€™s whispered name."No.. no.. I need to go to it." He sighed. "I need a bath. I smell like a whore." He complained.Evelyn lets out a breath she didnâ€™t realize sheâ€™d been holding. item.title: The Rosethorn Pact
item.description:
To the Camarilla (and the Prince), the Rosethorn Pact is whispered as nothing more than an Camarilla splinter movement â€” a philosophical cabal of rebels and dreamers seeking â€œKindred equality through beauty.â€ The Prince dismisses it as Toreador vanity and anarchic posturing.
In truth, the Rosethorn Pact is older than the Camarilla itself, a covenant of **Thirteen Signatories**, each bound by blood to an ancient oath whose purpose was never truly understood by later generations.
The Pact was created by two lovers: the First Toreador Prince of London and a philosopher Anarch, centuries ago.
Their â€œmarriage vowâ€ was sealed in vitae upon an obsidian rose â€” promising unity of Kindred and Kine through art and immortality.
Over time, the lovers perished, but the blood oath persisted â€” reforming into a ritual structure that demanded Thirteen signatories to â€œcompleteâ€ the circle. Every few centuries, the Pact seeks to â€œrenewâ€ itself by pulling in new Kindred whose vitae resonates with the original loversâ€™ lineage or ideals. Each of the Thirteen Thorns holds one vote within the Pactâ€™s tribunal. These votes, when combined, allow the Pact to override Camarilla decrees or enforce blood edicts within the sectâ€™s understructure. To outsiders, it looks like a secret political cabal. In reality, the voting system is the mechanism that channels vitae energy â€” the ritualâ€™s thirteenfold convergence that keeps the Obsidian Rose alive.
Sir Reginald Harker has been studying the Pact for decades. Heâ€™s discovered: The Pact is not political â€” itâ€™s a ritual of apotheosis.
When all Thirteen Thorns are bound (through death or oath), the Obsidian Rose will distill every drop of vitae ever pledged into a single Perfect Vitae â€” the Rose Chalice.
Whoever drinks it becomes the Thirteenth Bloom: the divine fusion of Kindred and Kine, Beastless and eternal. To achieve this:
Sir Reginald Harker arranged Lucian Valemontâ€™s Embrace so he could control his vote.
But when Lucienâ€™s Sire, Adrien Valemont died unexpectedly, Lucian Valemont killed him,, that control became uncertain.
Now, Sir Reginald Harker needs Lucian Valemontâ€™s signature and blood to complete the Pact â€” Lucien being unknowingly descended (or spiritually resonant) with the original loversâ€™ bloodline. When the Pact completes its Thirteen votes:
The Obsidian Rose reawakens. Every rose motif in London (paintings, carvings, stained glass) begins to bleed vitae.
Mortals are drawn into frenzied adoration, perceiving Kindred as divine muses â€” the Inverted Masquerade.
The Court of Roses manifests within Elysium, offering one chalice of Perfect Vitae.
Sir Reginald Harker believes he will drink it and become the God of Roses.
Lucian Valemont is the vessel the ritual was designed for.
The Prince, unaware of the true nature of the threat, will see only an Camarilla uprising and unleash hell on the city â€” becoming an unintentional antagonist in the awakening.In the final act, Lucien discovers: His Embrace wasnâ€™t random â€” he was chosen by blood prophecy. His Sireâ€™s death may have been orchestrated by Harker. His own vitae carries the resonance to complete the circle â€” meaning if he dies, Harker can ascend using his remains. The â€œPactâ€ is feeding off every drop of vitae spilled in London since its founding â€” itâ€™s already blooming beneath the city. Lucien must decide: Destroy the Pact, damning the souls of all bound to it â€” including his own Sireâ€™s memory. Usurp Harker, drink the chalice himself, becoming the Thirteenth Bloom. Feed it to the Prince, letting the mortal faÃ§ade collapse into chaos as London worships its new divine ruler. Let it fail, ensuring the Beast consumes everyone involved.

item.title: Adrian Vale
item.description: A student under Lucian Valemont. Became his Ghoul in Session 2Age: 24 Mortal Occupation: Postgraduate Literature Student, Kingâ€™s College London Background: Born in Bath, raised in a quiet academic family. His father a historian, his mother a painter of modest repute. Adrian grew up in old houses filled with books, portraits, and dust motes â€” the sort of world where silence itself feels curated.Appearance: Adrian carries a fragile sort of beauty â€” pale skin touched by sleeplessness, soft dark hair that never sits quite right, and eyes of deep grey that seem to drink in the world rather than look at it. His clothes are unassuming but thoughtful: charcoal coats, scarves even when not needed, a faint trace of ink on his fingers. His posture is composed yet uncertain, as if heâ€™s still learning how to inhabit his own body.When Lucien first sees him, thereâ€™s something familiar about him â€” the kind of youth Lucien once was: romantic, observant, a little haunted by beauty.Personality: Curious. Earnest. Too clever for his own good. Adrian is drawn to old things â€” books that smell of damp paper, poetry that aches with longing, men who carry the weight of centuries in their gaze. Beneath his intellect lies loneliness â€” a longing to belong somewhere that feels real.He speaks softly, listens intently, and asks questions that unsettle rather than flatter. When he talks about art or literature, itâ€™s with reverence â€” but when he talks to Lucien, thereâ€™s a tremor of awe, as though he senses the predator behind the poet.Connection to Lucien: Adrian visits The Velvet Veil archive while researching 19th-century vampire symbolism in Romantic literature. Lucien, intrigued by his insight and resemblance to a long-lost muse, begins to feed him knowledge â€” and eventually, blood. Their connection grows from mentorship to obsession: Adrian sees Lucien as both subject and story, and Lucien sees in Adrian a reflection of the youth he lost.To Lucien, Adrian Vale becomes the living canvas â€” a fragile mortal touched by art, desire, and the slow corrosion of eternity.

item.title: Session 1 Summary
item.description:
London, 2002 â€” the cityâ€™s Kindred society thrives under the shadow of Prince Adrian Welles. The nights are filled with rain, cigarette smoke, and the slow decay of the old order.
Lucian, a Toreador of Victorian origin and keeper of an archive called The Velvet Veil, receives a summons from his former lover and now Prince, Adrian Welles. The courtâ€™s Harpy, Marianne of Bath, has been found staked in her haven. Whispers of treachery ripple through Elysium.
Lucian arrives at the National Gallery, where Wellesâ€™ court holds vigil. Seneschal Elodie Rains greets him coldly, testing his composure. He deflects her probing questions about Marianneâ€™s death with charm and wit, drawing admiration and suspicion alike.
In the shadows, Lucian meets his Nosferatu contact, Grimshaw. The sewer-borne informant reveals that Marianneâ€™s last meeting wasnâ€™t with a Brujah revolutionary in Whitechapel â€” but with Sir Reginald Harker, Keeper of Elysium, in Knightsbridge.
Grimshaw passes Lucian a bloodstained notebook recovered from Marianneâ€™s haven. Inside, one phrase repeats: â€œThe Rosethorn Pactâ€Lucian presents the notebook to Prince Welles in private, masking his fear with devotion. The Prince is intrigued, remembering the name Rosethorn from decades past. He tasks Lucian to quietly watch for any sign of the Pact, entrusting him with his personal seal of protection and warning him that Harker will not take kindly to such knowledge.Lucian leaves the Princeâ€™s alcove under the watchful eyes of the court â€” and Harker himself.
Lucian accepts Harkerâ€™s invitation to a secluded lounge within Elysium. What follows is a conversation laced with manipulation, attraction, and power. Lucian submits outwardly, using intimacy as his weapon. Harker probes for information about what Lucian told the Prince; Lucian gives him only fragments and half-truths.When the meeting ends, Harker leaves behind a token â€” a black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.Grimshaw later identifies it as a mark of belonging to the Rosethorn Pact â€” a symbol worn by Marianne before her death. Lucian understands the implication: heâ€™s now publicly claimed as one of Harkerâ€™s possessions.
Lucian returns home through the wet streets of Camden. The rain on the windowpanes echoes the rhythm of his heartbeat. He stands before his mirror, staring at the rose on his lapel â€” both collar and key.He realizes the truth of his position: He must serve two masters â€” the Prince who once loved him and the Keeper who now owns him â€” while walking the razor edge between their secrets.As the city hums below, Lucian swears to himself that heâ€™ll play both sides until he can cut the strings from them all.Allies:
Prince Adrian Welles: trusts Lucian; granted him personal protection.
Grimshaw (Nosferatu): wary but loyal informant; manages secret communications. Enemies / Dangers:
Sir Reginald Harker: Keeper of Elysium, possible member of Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact; now considers Lucian his marked â€œproperty.â€
Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact: unknown purpose; connected to Marianneâ€™s murder and Kindred influence in Londonâ€™s elite. Lucianâ€™s Standing: Elevated status with the Prince. Dangerous attachment to Harker. Knowledge of a secret society that could destabilize Londonâ€™s Camarilla.

item.title: Session 2 Summary
item.description:
VTM V5 â€“ Session 2: â€œThe Thorns of Memoryâ€Chronicle: Velvet Veil Coterie Member: Lucian Valemont (Toreador) Setting: London, modern nightSession Summary
The session opened with Lucian awakening in The Velvet Veil, hunger gnawing after a sleepless day haunted by memories of the previous nightâ€™s encounter with Grimshaw and the word Rosethorn. His ghoul, Evelyn, brought him news of a deliveryâ€”an intended vessel for his hungerâ€”but Lucian, weary of mind and spirit, refused to feed on a stranger. The act of restraint foreshadowed the moral and emotional conflict that would define the night.
Later, a willing donorâ€” Adrian Vale, the Student, one of Lucianâ€™s regularsâ€”was brought to the library. Their interaction began as an intellectual exchange on Victorian vampiric myth and ended as a dark reflection of Lucianâ€™s own past, as he revealed himself and fed. The feeding was intimate but controlled, reaffirming his humanity rather than eroding it. The Student, enthralled and awed, became Lucianâ€™s new ghoul, marked with his personal sigil.Afterward, Lucian painted the youth as he sleptâ€”an act of creation and sin intertwinedâ€”and sealed his hunger in colour and canvas.
The following evening, Lucian descended into Londonâ€™s museum sub-basement, where he met Dr. Sebastian Crowe, the Curator of The Victoria & Albert Museum and recovered The Rosethorn Folio, a set of three vellum pages bearing the signatures of long-dead (and still-undead) aristocrats, including his own and that of his former master, Sir Reginald Harker. The tense exchange was interrupted by the arrival of Elias Crane, an agent of Harkerâ€™s, resulting in a standoff of old powers. Through cunning and the invocation of his lineage, Lucian claimed legal and personal ownership of the artefact.
Back home, he faced Sir Reginald himself, whose visit turned into a familiar but fraught power game. Their relationshipâ€”part devotion, part manipulationâ€”culminated in a reminder of the elderâ€™s control and a warning about the Rosethornâ€™s origins. Reginald revealed that the Lady Marianne of Bath, one of the covenantâ€™s founders, had died by her own will, seeking to sever the blood-bonded pact that still haunts them all.Lucian did not believe him.
Drained but resolute, Lucian fed lightly from Evelyn in a moment of hunger and remorse, reaffirming his humanity with his restraint and affection. The session closed with a meeting between Lucian and Prince Adrien, his oldest friend and the ruler of Londonâ€™s Kindred. Adrien, aware of the Rosethornâ€™s resurfacing, demanded Lucianâ€™s loyaltyâ€”but the two shared a rare, honest exchange about their friendship, their vows, and the ghosts of their shared past.Lucian left the Princeâ€™s office torn between duty to his ruler and an older, darker allegiance bound in blood and secrecy.Key Outcomes
The Rosethorn Folio Acquired: The ancient document listing the founding members of the covenant, including Lucian, Reginald, and the late Lady Marianne of Bath, now rests in Lucianâ€™s personal vault.
New Ghoul Created: The Student, Adrian Vale, is now bound to Lucian and branded with his sign.Sir Reginaldâ€™s Influence Reignited: Reginaldâ€™s manipulation and warnings hint at deeper conspiracies within the covenant.Prince Adrien Informed: Adrien is aware of the folioâ€™s existence but not its contents. He trusts Lucianâ€”for now.Humanity Check Passed: Despite predatory acts, Lucianâ€™s remorse and tenderness preserved his soul.
Political Stakes Raised: The Rosethorn Pact threatens to expose a web of blood oaths among Londonâ€™s elite Kindred.Session Tone & ThemesGothic decadence and moral decayLove versus loyaltyArt as confessionPredation intertwined with tendernessThe weight of immortal memory

item.title: ChatGPT-VTM V5 session 1
item.description: Created: 10/22/2025 15:41:34 London, 2002. It rains like it always does â€” soft, constant, and silver on the windows of Lucianâ€™s unassuming flat in Camden. Beneath the mundane surface lies The Velvet Veil, a hidden chamber of art, relics, and the scent of forgotten roses.Word has reached the Toreador court: Prince Adrian Welles, the centuries-old ruler of London, is hosting a private salon at his Elysium tonight â€” ostensibly to unveil a new art installationâ€¦ but rumor speaks of a power vacuum.The Harpy of London, Marianne of Bath, was found staked in her haven three nights ago. Someone has been feeding the Prince false reports, and suspicion falls on every clan.An invitation, written in expensive cream parchment, rests on Lucianâ€™s piano: â€œYour taste and counsel are required, darling Lucian. â€” A.â€ The venue is the National Gallery, long closed to the public this evening. Candlelight flickers against oil paintings â€” Rembrandt, Turner, Rossetti â€” while Kindred mingle in murmurs and false smiles.Prince Adrian stands near the dais, his pale hand resting on a silver-topped cane. The Seneschal, a Ventrue named Elodie Rains, approaches you first, her gaze like polished glass. Elodie: â€œLucian. You grace us at last. The Prince will be most eager to hear yourâ€¦ aesthetic insights. But between us â€” what did Marianne tell you before she perished? You two wereâ€¦ familiar.â€ Sheâ€™s probing. In public. A test of composure and loyalty."My lady Rains.." Lucian made an elegant overexagerated bow, wearing a fine open tunic shirt in the Neuve noir style, open neck and frills. tight leather trousers and knee high boots."It is a heartbreak the moment I heard that Lady Marianne was... you know.." He made a steaking motion into his chest. "First of all, I have not spoken to her in a few months."Elodie Rains watches your performance with an expression that doesnâ€™t quite reach her eyes. The Seneschalâ€™s lips twitch â€” not a smile, but the ghost of one. Around you, the chatter of Kindred grows hushed; a few Toreador hang on your words like admirers at a salon performance. Elodie: â€œMm. I see your flair for drama remains intact.â€ She takes a step closer, voice a whisper meant for you alone. â€œCareful, Lucian. The Prince isâ€¦ disturbed by her death. And he has already tasked the Hounds with finding her killer. If he suspects your silence hides something, it will not end with words.â€ She brushes past, perfume faint and cold. You can feel her intent â€” she wanted to warn youâ€¦ or perhaps to see how you react when cornered.At that moment, someone else approaches: A short man in a dark velvet coat, hair slicked back like oil â€” Grimshaw, your Nosferatu contact. He gives a subtle bow, eyes darting toward a quiet corner behind a sculpture of St. Michael. Grimshaw (low voice): â€œGot something for you, Luci. Marianneâ€™s last meeting wasnâ€™t in Whitechapel like everyone says. It was in Knightsbridge. And she wasnâ€™t with a Brujah â€” she was meeting someone from Elysium.â€ He pauses, a grin splitting his sallow face. â€œGuess who.â€ Lucian looks a little offended at Elodie as he puts his hand on his chest. "My lady, you wound me with those accusations. I am a loyal servent of the Prince and the Camarilla since my introduction all those years ago. I have done nothing but be honest and open with all who come to me and those who summon me." He nodded softly.Turning to Grimshaw, Lucian nodded and motioned. "As you see, I have pulled favours to find out what had happened, Although Whitechapel is a horrible place, Knightsbridge even more so..." He turned to the contact. "Who?"Lovelyâ€”Lucianâ€™s injured dignity plays like music through the hall. The surrounding Kindred murmur with subtle appreciation; even Elodie seems momentarily disarmed by his gallant tone. She offers only a curt nod before drifting off to attend to another guest.Now the spotlight narrows to you and Grimshaw, tucked behind the sculptureâ€™s marble wings. The low buzz of the salon becomes a distant hum, the scent of candlewax and aged wine hanging between you.Grimshawâ€™s eyes dart left and right before he speaks, his voice a conspiratorial rasp. Grimshaw: â€œMarianne met with Sir Reginald Harker. You know himâ€”Keeper of Elysium, Toreador like yourself, all white gloves and quiet cruelty. The Prince trusts him more than anyone. Or used to.â€ He produces a thin, leather-bound notebook, small enough to hide in a sleeve. The edges are stained with something dark. â€œFound this in Marianneâ€™s haven. Mentions The Rosethorn Pact. Donâ€™t know what that is yet, but whatever she learned got her killed.â€ He glances toward the Princeâ€™s dais. â€œYou tell Welles, and heâ€™ll tear Elysium apart looking for scapegoats. You tell Harker, and heâ€™ll bury you under a dozen compliments and call it art. My advice? Keep your head low until you know which oneâ€™s the spider.â€ He pauses, half-grinning. â€œUnless youâ€™re feeling brave, Luci.â€ "Well dont you have my balls in a vice my little impish friend." he sighed, running his hand down his face, before approaching the Prince, more pomp and elegance as he bowedLucianâ€™s boots click softly on the marble as he strides through the candlelit gallery. The gathered Kindred part like curtains, watching with a mix of envy and dread as he approaches the dais.Prince Adrian Welles stands before Turnerâ€™s â€œThe Fighting Temeraireâ€, the faint glow of its golden horizon reflected in his pale eyes. A beautiful corpse admiring another. His voice, when he speaks, is gentle â€” too gentle. Welles: â€œLucian. The rose among brambles.â€ He turns, a faint smile ghosting his lips. â€œMarianneâ€™s death wounds us all. You were close to her. Tell meâ€¦ do you mourn her as I do?â€ He gestures for you to rise. The Seneschal, Elodie, lingers just out of earshot â€” clearly watching.Now is your moment. You can present the notebook and shape the narrative."She will be missed, my Prince. I was fond of her, she had an air and perfume that I much enjoyed being around. Plus, her tits were to die for." He chuckled softly to himself."I... I am torn my Prince. A contact of mine whom I sent to investigate upon hearing the act, found something that would put me at a disadvantage to all sides. I fear for my safety, not from you my Prince, you are as ever, a graceful and honrouable patron.. " He bowed again. "But I am fearful of those who did this to our dearest Marianne. If I may, I wish to approach and bring this to your attention, without the prying eyes of those around."The humor cuts through the tension like a fine edge â€” daring, irreverent, Toreador to the bone. The Princeâ€™s expression doesnâ€™t change at first, but a corner of his mouth betrays the faintest ghost of amusement. A ripple of whispers passes through the court â€” Lucian always did dance on knives.Welles raises a pale hand, and immediately, the chatter dies. The room grows so silent you can hear the rain tapping against the galleryâ€™s grand windows. Welles: â€œVery well, Lucian. Let us step aside.â€ His voice is soft but heavy, carrying the kind of command that brooks no refusal. He gestures toward a curtained alcove â€” a private annex lined with portraits of mortal nobles long dead. Once inside, the velvet curtains close behind you, muting the outside world. The Prince turns, his eyes sharp now, the veneer of charm fading into something ancient. Welles: â€œShow me.â€ You remove the notebook, holding it delicately as if it might crumble. Its worn leather glints in the flickering light.The Prince accepts it carefully, opening to the page marked by a torn ribbon â€” The Rosethorn Pact. His brows knit slightly. Welles: â€œThisâ€¦ name. I have not heard it in decades.â€ He looks up, meeting your gaze. â€œYou were wise to bring this to me. But tell me â€” who gave you this?â€ You feel the weight of the question. His voice is calm, but thereâ€™s an edge, like the hush before a predatorâ€™s lunge. Grimshawâ€™s name burns at the back of your throat â€” valuable, but dangerous."A contact of mine found it in her belongings.. He is, well.. not one for the glamour of the light. If you catch my drift..."Welles studies you for several long seconds. The candlelight catches his eyes â€” ancient, cold, and strangelyâ€¦ amused. Welles: â€œAh. The shadows speak to you, then.â€ He closes the notebook slowly, fingers tapping its cover as if testing the rhythm of a waltz. â€œThat pleases me. The Camarilla needs those who listen to whispers, not those who shout them.â€ He takes a half-step closer, lowering his voice to something confidential â€” almost intimate. Welles: â€œYou have done well, Lucian. If this Rosethorn Pact stirs again, I want you to be my eyes and my voice in that dark. Bring me what you find. Quietly.â€ â€œIn returnâ€¦â€ he glances toward the curtain, where Elodie waits like a statue, â€œâ€¦I will see that you are protected from whatever wolves stalk this court.â€ He places the notebook into his coat. The moment feels sealed, heavy with unseen consequence.Then, with the faintest smile: Welles: â€œTell me, my rose â€” do you trust Sir Reginald Harker?â€ You realize this is not idle curiosity. The Prince is measuring you. He knows youâ€™ve already considered the possibility.This is the pivotal point â€” your words will shape how Welles moves next: whether Harker becomes an ally, an enemy, or a target.He pauses, thinking for a moment."I have not had the pleasure of his courtie but I have heard about him. And the rumours in the circles of his actions. I honestly have no opinion on him as of yet my Prince."Welles regards you for a long moment, his stillness unnerving. Then, slowly, the Princeâ€™s expression softens â€” the faintest curl of a satisfied smile. Welles: â€œSpoken like a true servant of the Camarilla. A man of reason amid a sea of passion.â€ He steps closer, lowering his tone so only you can hear. â€œHold to that composure, Lucian. The nights ahead will tempt you to passion â€” and in passion, the Toreador are at their weakest.â€ He reaches into his coat and produces a small, folded card of thick, cream parchment. The Princeâ€™s personal seal â€” black wax embossed with a rose and crown. Welles: â€œTake this. Present it to my Herald should you require sanctuary, or should anyone question your place in this court. You have done me a service tonight.â€ He looks toward the curtain. â€œNow go, my rose. Enjoy the music. And keep your eyes open. Harker will not rest easy when he learns his name passed through your lips â€” even so gently.â€ With that, he turns away, leaving you with the faint scent of sandalwood and old paper.Back in the main hall, the atmosphere has shifted â€” murmurs ripple through the gathered Kindred. You notice Sir Reginald Harker himself standing by the piano, surrounded by lesser Toreador. He raises a glass of dark vitae toward you, a sly smile touching his lips.Youâ€™ve barely taken three steps when Grimshaw sidles back up beside you, whispering low: Grimshaw: â€œYou did it, didnâ€™t you? Whatever you said, the Princeâ€™s pet ghoul just left Elysium in a hurry. Looks like someoneâ€™s about to get visited.â€ He smirks. â€œSo, what now, Luci? You going to let the old manâ€™s hounds handle it, or dig deeper yourself before the trailâ€™s cold?â€ Taking his hand as the card is handed, Lucian kisses it gently; a loving kiss. A submissive kiss. One that had been shared many years ago on warm nights with a fledgling soon to be Prince and the artist before him."Yes my Prince. "returning, he takes a glass of blood and downs it in one, not able to even take the time to savour it. Raising the empty glass to Sir Reginald.Looking to grimshaw, he sighs."I'm going to do what my Prince requires. I am going into the den of lions as a little lamb. I know sir Reginald has a thing for those of my... appearance and virvor.. We will bed, and we will talk against the pillow, as all do."Grimshaw huffs out a low, wet laugh â€” the sound of a gutter-born man genuinely impressed. Grimshaw: â€œYou mad, shining bastard. Youâ€™re going to let the spider wrap you up and call it art.â€ He glances around, lowers his voice. â€œFine. Iâ€™ll keep an ear to the sewers. If the hounds start sniffinâ€™ too close, Iâ€™ll send word. You justâ€¦ donâ€™t get eaten.â€ He melts back into the crowd, swallowed by marble and shadow.You make your way across the gallery. Harker is waiting â€” immaculate as a statue, one hand resting on a cane thatâ€™s more ornament than support. His gaze follows you, appreciative in the way collectors study paintings they already own. Harker: â€œLucian. The Princeâ€™s favorite pet graces my corner. Youâ€™ve been avoiding me, havenâ€™t you? I do hope itâ€™s not fear.â€ He steps closer, voice dropping to a purr. Harker: â€œYou lookâ€¦ exquisite tonight. Come â€” drink with me. I insist.â€ He gestures toward a secluded lounge where the candles burn lower and the whispers sound like sighs. The table glitters with crystal and silver, and the air smells faintly of rosewater and blood.You sit. The dance begins.Harker leans forward, eyes glittering. Harker: â€œThey say you brought something interesting to our Prince. You wouldnâ€™t happen to know what that might be, would you?â€ He smiles, thin and knowing â€” the smile of a man who already suspects, and is waiting to see how gracefully you lie."No far at all My Lord Sire." Lucian bows and curtsies. Taking his hand and kissing it softly."I've just been so gathered with so much work in the painters alley that I've been unable to be torn away from the muses." He chuckled softly. The tone, the voice, the purr, the sly hand slipped down the back of his trousers to prod his opening with a single finger..Intent, he all but knew."Ofcourse my lord sire.. I wouldn't think of anything I'd want to do more." He gasped softly, following him into the lounge and sitting beside him.Leg crossed, one hanging over Harker's leg, Lucian pressed up against Harker, he spoke softly, playing with the older's hair with an eblow on the sofa back behind him."There was the death of one of a close friends of ours... he asked if I knew anything. An old contact of mine brought me a letter he found, to some Nosferatu working for the Anarchists..." He lied, half lied."The Prince is going to search there way." He sighed, a needy husky submissive sigh as he sipped the blood in the wine glassThe lounge feels smaller than it is. The air is perfumed with dust, velvet, and vitae. Harker allows the nearness â€” even encourages it â€” a faint smirk curling his mouth as Lucianâ€™s charm bleeds into the moment. For the Toreador, proximity is conversation; the body is punctuation. Harker: â€œAhâ€¦ the muses. They are such jealous lovers.â€ His fingers trace the rim of his glass. â€œYou do them justice, Lucian. Even your lies are painted beautifully.â€ He tilts his head, eyes narrowing in faint amusement. Harker: â€œSo the Prince sends his hounds to the sewers. Convenient. Keeps his gaze away from the gallery, doesnâ€™t it?â€ A pause. The mask slips â€” just a flicker, but Lucian sees it: the tiniest tightening of the jaw, a ripple of irritation that he hides behind a smile. Harker: â€œTell me, my dear, did yourâ€¦ contact happen to mention what this letter said? Or did you leave that part out to make me chase it from your lips?â€ The question is bait. You can feel it. Heâ€™s not sure what you know â€” but heâ€™s fishing, testing whether the Prince told you anything real. The wine-dark candlelight glints across his signet ring â€” engraved with a thorned rose.With their lips almost close, faces so close as if to kiss, but not... The two sat there, Lucian pressed against him like a good submissive toy."I did not read it. The Prince's dog summoned me. I dont get involved in the court's dealings. I am just an archivist, collector, painter and... lover.."The line lands softly, but it hits its mark. Harkerâ€™s eyes stay on yours a long moment â€” weighing, measuring, wondering whether to believe the meekness or enjoy it. He lets the pause stretch until it hums. Harker: â€œA loverâ€¦ and yet, you find yourself in the centre of a Princeâ€™s investigation.â€ He smiles faintly. â€œThat, my dear Lucian, is why I adore artists. You pretend not to play the game, and still, you always end up on the stage.â€ He straightens, the air cooling between you. The mask returns, voice smooth once more. Harker: â€œKeep to your paints for now. If His Grace asks, tell him that I am as loyal as ever. You may even tell him I toasted to Marianneâ€™s memory tonight.â€ His smile doesnâ€™t reach his eyes. â€œAnd if the Rosethorn nonsense resurfaces again, come to me first. We mustnâ€™t trouble the Prince with rumours.â€ He stands, adjusts his cuffs, then glances back down at you. Harker: â€œYou wear obedience beautifully, Lucian. But rememberâ€”submission can be a kind of art, too. Practise it wisely.â€ He leaves you in the low light, the sound of the chamber orchestra drifting faintly from the gallery beyond. On the table beside his half-empty glass lies something he must have meant you to notice: a small pressed rose, its petals darkened to near black and pricked through with a silver pin.Grimshaw appears a few minutes later, lurking in the doorway, eyes darting between you and the abandoned flower. Grimshaw: â€œWell? You live. Thatâ€™s somethinâ€™. Whatâ€™s that he left ya?â€ Hearing the Rosethorn word, he almost coughed at it, but kept his face submissivly passive."Ofcourse.. my lord sire.." He said softly, slowly sliding down the sofa until he was on his knee's between the Lord's legs. A sharp nailed hand running through his silvery white hair.Fade to blackAfter Harker had left the alchove; Lucian sprawled on the leather sofa in the quiet slcohove, Using a paper fan to cool himself down, "Shut up you disgusting rat." Lucian's mask dropped for once. He picked up the glass rose, inspecting it close as he pinned it to his lapel."Its a whore bitches collar. To tell the world who's bitch I am." He growled. "What do you want.."You can almost hear the gallery again now that Harkerâ€™s presence is goneâ€”the faint scrape of a bow across strings, the hush of other conversations resuming once the Princeâ€™s Keeper has taken his leave.Grimshaw steps a little further inside. Heâ€™s still smiling, but itâ€™s the kind of grin that hides nerves rather than delight. Grimshaw: â€œEasy, Luci. You still got both eyes and a heartbeatâ€”undead as it is. Thatâ€™s a win in my book.â€ He gestures with a stubby finger toward the pinned rose. Grimshaw: â€œThat thingâ€™s got teeth, though. You feel it? Thereâ€™s a symbol etched on the pinâ€”tiny, under the clasp. Old sigil the Nosferatu trade around; it means property of the Rosethorn. Marianne had one in her haven too, same metal. Whoever wears itâ€™s marked as belonging to the Pact, or claimed by it.â€ He crouches beside the couch, voice dropping lower. Grimshaw: â€œYou just got drafted into their little club, whether you like it or not. Question is: you gonna wear the leash and see where it leads, or cut it off before they start tugging?â€ He straightens, waiting, his expression halfway between admiration and worry."The man just fucked me, used me and told me in no uncertain terms I'm his bitch, and that he is involved. THIS is exactly what you said it is. And its not your business to know what I do with it." He growled. "And you'll probably sell this information to anyone who asks or pays you enough." He sighed, standing up, pulling up his trousers and fastening his belt, brushing his fingers through his hair and checking his stained self in the reflection of a nearby picture frame."The Prince was a brother to me, a lover, one of my closest companions. I serve him, but this.." He flicked the rose. "Is all part of serving my Prince. I have to play both sides."Grimshaw lifts both hands, palms out, the smirk fading. Grimshaw: â€œEasy, easy. You donâ€™t owe me your soul, Luci. Youâ€™re rightâ€”I deal in whispers, not faith. But I ainâ€™t stupid enough to sell a rumour thatâ€™s got the Prince and Harker both stitched into it.â€ He waits while you straighten yourself, eyes flicking toward the curtained doorway. Grimshaw: â€œAll right. You play the pretty pawn. Just remember pawns bleed first when the board flips.â€ He hesitates, then adds quietly: Grimshaw: â€œIf you need to pass something to Welles without anyone seeinâ€™ you together, leave it at the old tube station in Camden Town. The one they never reopened after the Blitz. Iâ€™ll make sure it reaches him.â€ He melts back toward the shadows, voice dropping to a rasp. Grimshaw: â€œWatch Harkerâ€™s temper. The man collects people the way you collect paintings. And when he gets boredâ€¦â€ The rest is lost in the din of the gallery as he disappears.Lucian is alone again. The faint strings of the orchestra drift through the curtains. Outside this little alcove, the Elysiumâ€™s glittering court has resumed its danceâ€”none of them yet realising that the game has changed.The rose on your lapel catches the light, a small glint of silver and black.Youâ€™ve gained: The Princeâ€™s favour â€” protection and access. Harkerâ€™s mark â€” leverage and danger. Grimshawâ€™s channel â€” a way to move in the dark unseen. He threw the empty glass at the cloth curtain covering the door to get Grimshaw to leave.With a sigh, he goes home.The glass hits the curtain with a sharp, hollow clink, rolls across the marble, and disappears into the folds. The sound is enough; you hear Grimshawâ€™s boots scuff once, then fade completely.Outside, Londonâ€™s rain has turned from mist to a steady downpour. The streets are slick mirrors of sodium light. By the time Lucian reaches his building in Camden, the night smells of wet stone and paint thinner â€” the scent of his own exile.Inside, The Velvet Veil waits just as he left it: canvases leaning against walls, half-finished studies of faces he canâ€™t quite forget. The only sound is the soft ticking of an antique clock and the occasional sigh of pipes behind the plaster.He peels off the damp shirt, hangs the coat where it always hangs. The rose glints faintly in the mirror, the tiny silver pin catching the roomâ€™s lone bulb. A reminder. A claim.For a moment, Lucianâ€™s reflection looks like the boy who once knelt before a fledgling artist turned Prince, full of hope and devotion. Then the illusion breaks, leaving only the pale creature with too many debts and not enough time to pay them.He pours himself another glass, this time not pretending to taste it. The city hums below â€” its heartbeat slow and secret. Allies: Prince Adrian Welles â€” trusts you, for now. You hold his personal seal. Grimshaw (Nosferatu) â€” wary ally, courier of secrets. Enemies / Dangers: Sir Reginald Harker â€” Keeper of Elysium, probable member of the Rosethorn Pact. Has â€œmarkedâ€ you as his. The Rosethorn Pact â€” unknown purpose, tied to Marianneâ€™s death. Current Status: You are walking a double line between the Prince and Harker. The mark makes you both protected and exposed. Knightsbridge remains the last confirmed site connected to the Pact.

item.title: Elysium
item.description:
Elysium is neutral ground for the Camarilla vampires of a given city.
[
](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/whitewolf/images/9/96/SymbolElysiumVTMB.png/revision/latest?cb=20220330051910)
Elysium: A place for vampires to meet together without fear of harm; Usually cultural locations, such as opera houses, theaters or museums.1(https://whitewolf.fandom.com/wiki/Elysium_\(VTM\)#cite_note-1)
The Elysium location is typically chosen by the local Prince in areas of artistic or intellectual worth that promote calm reflection, such as theaters and museums, though nightclubs and even a Kindred's haven may suffice.
Violence is strictly prohibited within Elysium, and individuals are expected to keep tempers in check. Any grievances between vampires are to be left outside, and the Keeper of Elysium or the Sheriff will forcibly remove those who cannot control themselves if need be. While this provides opportunity for both neonates and elders to relax, social conflict is often at its peak and what happens in Elysium can easily lead to repercussions off ground.
Though Elysiums often serve as gathering places for Kindred, the Masquerade must normally be maintained at all times for any mortals that may be around. Similarly, while refreshments are sometimes served, it is bad taste to come to Elysium hungry as it often leads to shorter tempers. Some Princes go so far as to forbid hunting nearby, as a concentrated population of vampires could easily result in a suspicious number of deaths in the area.

item.title: Keeper of Elysium
item.description:
[
](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/whitewolf/images/f/f7/KeeperOfElysium.png/revision/latest?cb=20210920030833)Keeper of Elysium Vampire: The Masquerade - BloodhuntThis is a largely honorific title, though it has many practical responsibilities. The Keeper of Elysium assures that the customs of Elysium are observed, and is a caretaker of sites declared Elysium by a Prince.It is the Keeper who may schedule or cancel any events, a position that involves both great prestige and scrutiny.
